AN ZOOR14912063548
DT Article
TI A new Rowlandius Reddell & Cokendolpher 1995 from Sierra Maestra,
   eastern Cuba (Schizomida: Hubbardiidae).
FT Un nuevo Rowlandius Reddell & Cokendolpher 1995 de la Sierra Maestra,
   Cuba oriental (schizomida: Hubbardiidae).
AU Teruel, Rolando (rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu) 
   de Armas, Luis F.
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 5-8
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 4
AB Rowlandius guama sp.n. is described upon specimens of both sexes
   collected from a single coastal locality in the southern Sierra Maestra
   mountains, in Santiago de Cuba province. According to the morphology of
   the male pedipalps and flagellum, as well as the female spermathecae,
   this species is very closely related to Rowlandius serrano Teruel, 2003
   and Rowlandius vinai Teruel, 2003, both also occurring at the Sierra
   Maestra.
C1 Teruel, Rolando; Museo Hist Nat Tomas Ramey, Ctr Oriental Ecosistemas
   Biodivers BIOECO, Jose A Saco 601, Santiago De Cuba, 90100, Cuba, Cuba.
EM rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America; West Indies
DE Rowlandius guama [Cuba /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Schizomida
OR Rowlandius guama (Schizomida): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 5]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912063548

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE TRAPDOOR SPIDERS GENUS IDIOPS PERTY, 1833 (ARANEAE:
   IDIOPIDAE) FROM THE WESTERN GHATS, WITH A KEY TO THE IDIOPS OF INDIA.
AU Mirza, Zeeshan A. (snakeszeeshan@gmail.com) 
   Vaze, Varun V.
   Sanap, Rajesh V.
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 9-14
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species of the trapdoor spider genus Idiops Perty, Idiops
   kaasensis sp. n., is described from Kaas Plateau in the Satara District
   (Western Ghats, Maharashtra, India). A key to the known Indian species
   of the genus is presented.
C1 Mirza, Zeeshan A.; GKVK, Tata Inst Fundamental Res, F-21,Bellary Rd,
   Bangalore, Karnataka, 560065, India, India.
EM snakeszeeshan@gmail.com

   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Idiops [India /  / Key to species]. 
   Idiops kaasensis [Maharashtra /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

OR Idiops - Perty 1833 (Araneae): [Key to species, India, Modified key, p.
   13]. 
   Idiops kaasensis (Araneae): [Sp nov, Maharashtra, P. 10].

PT J
AN ZOOR14912063551
DT Article
TI A new species of Buthus Leach, 1815 (Scorpiones, Buthidae), from
   northern Morocco; possible link between Moroccan and European
   populations.
FT Un nouveau Buthus Leach, 1815 (scorpiones, buthidae) du nord du maroc;
   possible lien entre les populations marocaines et europeennes.
AU Lourenco, Wilson R. (arachne@mnhn.fr) 
   Touloun, Oulaid
   Boumezzough, Ali
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 21-25
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species belonging to the genus Buthus Leach, 1815 (Scorpiones:
   Buthidae) is described from the region of Alhamra near the road between
   Chefchaouen and Tetouan, in northern Morocco. Buthus confluens sp. n.,
   shows clear morphological affinities with Buthus ibericus, described
   from Cadiz province in southern Spain. The new species may represent the
   first known link between African and European species of Buthus.
C1 Lourenco, Wilson R.; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Systemat & Evolut, CP
   053,57 Rue Cuvier, Paris, F-75005, France, France.
EM arachne@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Africa
DE Buthus confluens [Morocco /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Buthus confluens (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Morocco, P. 22]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912063551

DT Article
TI A new species of Paraphrynus Moreno, 1940 (Amblypygi: Phrynidae) from
   Mexico and the south-west of the United States.
FT Nueva especie de Paraphrynus Moreno, 1940 (amblypygi: Phrynidae) de
   Mexico y el suroeste de los ee.uu. De america.
AU de Armas, Luis F. (dearmas@ecologia.cu) 
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 27-32
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 3
AB The population of Paraphrynus Moreno, 1940 from the south-west of the
   USA (Arizona, California), and north-western and central-western Mexico
   (Sonora, Michoacan, and Morelos), which was previously misidentified as
   Paraphrynus mexicanus (Bilimek, 1867), is described as a new species.
   The diagnosis of P. mexicanus is also emended.
C1 de Armas, Luis F.; Apartado Postal 4327, San Antonio De Los Banos,
   Artemisa, 32500, Cuba, Cuba.
EM dearmas@ecologia.cu

DT Article
TI Oribatids (Acari, Oribatida) from the Guadalquivir valley (southern
   Spain). Description of Bullibates hygrophilus n. gen., n. sp
   (Hermanniellidae).
FT Oribatidos (acari, Oribatida) de la ribera del rio Guadalquivir (sur de
   espana). Descripcion de Bullibates hygrophilus n. Gen., n. Sp.
   (hermanniellidae).
AU Subias, Luis S. (subias@bio.ucm.es) 
   Shtanchaeva, Umukusum Ya.
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 33-37
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 3
AB Oribatid mites from soil samples taken in the riverside of the
   Guadalquivir valley in Cordoba province (Andalusia, southern Spain) are
   studied. A total of 86 species were identified. A new genus and species
   of the family Hermanniellidae, Bullibates hygrophilus n. gen., n. sp.,
   are described. 27 species are also recorded for the first time from
   Andalusia.
C1 Subias, Luis S.; Univ Complutense, Fac Biol, Madrid, E-28040, Spain,
   Spain.
EM subias@bio.ucm.es
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Bullibates hygrophilus [Spain /  / New species]. 
   Oribatida [Spain / Andalusia / New record]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Bullibates (Acari): [Gen nov, Of family Hermanniellidae, Type species
   Bullibates hygrophilus, p. 34]. 
   Bullibates hygrophilus (Acari): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 34]. 
   Oribatida (Acari): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14912063555
DT Article
TI MOLECULAR AND MORPHOLOGICAL EVIDENCE SUPPORTS THE ELEVATION OF
   EUSCORPIUS GERMANUS CROATICUS DI CAPORIACCO, 1950 (SCORPIONES:
   EUSCORPIIDAE) TO E. CROATICUS STAT. NOV., A RARE SPECIES FROM CROATIA.
AU Graham, Matthew R.
   Webber, Michael M.
   Blagoev, Gergin
   Ivanova, Natalia
   Fet, Victor
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 41-50
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The taxonomic identity of Euscorpius germanus croaticus Di Caporiacco,
   1950, described from Croatia and Bosnia, has remained unclear ever since
   its discovery. We studied the lectotype from the Velebit Mountains as
   well as new material from Biserujka Cave on Krk Island, Croatia. We
   reassessed E. g. croaticus using both morphology and DNA barcodes (cox1
   sequences) from one of the Biserujka Cave specimens and 15 congeneric
   species. The resulting DNA phylogeny suggests that E. g. croaticus is
   not a subspecies of E. germanus. The taxon appears to be a separate
   lineage, which groups close to subgenus Alpiscorpius but differs from
   all its members in several morphological characters. We elevate E. g.
   croaticus to species rank as Euscorpius croaticus Di Caporiacco, 1950,
   stat. nov., and provide a detailed redescription of both sexes.
C1 Graham, Matthew R.; Univ Nevada, Sch Life Sci, 4505 South Maryland Pkwy,
   Las Vegas, NV, 89154, USA, USA.
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Taxonomy; Status
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Euscorpius croaticus - Di Caporiacco 1950 (Scorpiones): [Redescription,
   Male, p.44, Female, p. 46; Raised from, Euscorpius germanus croaticus,
   p. 43, Cited by author as stat.nov]. 
   Euscorpius germanus croaticus - Di Caporiacco 1950 (Scorpiones): [Raised
   to, Euscorpius croaticus, p. 43, Cited by author as stat.nov]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912063555
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14912063556
DT Article
TI Description of a new species of the genus Filistatinella Gertsch & Ivie,
   1936 (Araneae: Filistatidae) from Toluca, Mexico.
FT Descripcion de una nueva especie del genero Filistatinella Gertsch &
   Ivie, 1936 (araneae: Filistatidae) de Toluca, Mexico.
AU Antonio Desales-Lara, Marco (madesales@gmail.com) 
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 51-55
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB Filistatinella domestica sp. nov. is described, based on specimens
   collected inside buildings in Toluca, Estado de Mexico. This species is
   characterized by the structure of the male palp, whose embolus never
   exceeds the basal part of the tibia, the presence of basal teeth (DBT)
   and a hook (GT) on the tibia in retrolateral and prolateral views,
   respectively. In the females the spermathecae are tube-shaped, becoming
   wider distally. Mating is inferred to take place from October to
   February, because in these months both adult males and females are
   present; it is important to note that from March to July there were no
   adult males.
C1 Antonio Desales-Lara, Marco; Univ Autonoma Estado Mexico, Lab Zool
   Invertebrados, Campus Cerrillo Km 15 Carr Toluca Ixtlahuac, Toluca,
   50200, Mexico, Mexico.
EM madesales@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America
DE Filistatinella domestica [Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Filistatinella domestica (Araneae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 52]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912063556
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14912063559
DT Article
TI A new Rowlandius Reddell & Cokendolpher 1995 from Guamuhaya mountains,
   central Cuba (Schizomida: Hubbardiidae).
FT Un nuevo Rowlandius Reddell & Cokendolpher 1995 del macizo de Guamuhaya,
   Cuba central (schizomida: Hubbardiidae).
AU Teruel, Rolando (rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu) 
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 61-64
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Rowlandius martinezi sp.n. is described from a single heteromorphic male
   collected in a cave of the Guamuhaya mountains, Sancti Spiritus province
   (Cuba). According to the morphology of the male pedipalps and flagellum,
   this species is very closely related to four others from the same
   mountain chain: Rowlandius biconourus (Rowland & Reddell 1979),
   Rowlandius ramosi Armas 2007, Rowlandius recuerdo (Armas 1989), and
   Rowlandius tomasi Armas 2007.
C1 Teruel, Rolando; Museo Hist Nat Tomas Romay Jose A Saco 601, Ctr
   Oriental Ecosistemas & Biodiversidad BIOECO, Esquina A Barnada, Santiago
   De Cuba, 90100, Cuba, Cuba.
EM rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America; West Indies
DE Rowlandius martinezi [Cuba /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Schizomida
OR Rowlandius martinezi (Schizomida): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 61]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912063559

AN ZOOR14912063561
DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Microtityus Kjellesvig-Waering, 1966 (Scorpiones:
   Buthidae) in the Dominican Republic.
FT Revision del genero Microtityus Kjellesvig-Waering, 1966 (scorpiones:
   Buthidae) en republica dominicana.
AU de Armas, Luis F. (dearmas@ecologia.cu) 
   Teruel, Rolando
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 69-88
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB The scorpions of the genus Microtityus Kjellesvig-Waering, 1966 of the
   Dominican Republic are revised, and five new species, all of them
   previously misidentified, are described; also, a sixth species is
   identified but not formally named. Diagnoses are emended for the
   subgenera Microtityus Kjellesvig-Waering, 1966 and Parvabsonus Armas,
   1974, and for all the Dominican species. With those additions the number
   of Dominican species of this genus rises to 11. Microtityus starri
   Lourenco & Huber, 1999 is restored as a valid taxon, whereas M.
   ambarensis (Schawaller, 1982) is transferred to the subgenus
   Parvabsonus.
C1 de Armas, Luis F.; Apartado Postal 4327, San Antonio De Los Banos,
   Artemisa, 32500, Cuba, Cuba.
EM dearmas@ecologia.cu
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America;
   West Indies
DE Microtityus barahona; Microtityus lourencoi; Microtityus prendinii;
   Microtityus reini; Microtityus solegladi [Dominican Republic /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Microtityus - Kjellesvig-Waering 1966 (Scorpiones): [Revision, P. 70;
   Diagnostic characters of subordinate taxa, P. 72]. 
   Microtityus (Microtityus) - Kjellesvig-Waering 1966 (Scorpiones):
   [Emended diagnosis, P. 70]. 
   Microtityus (Microtityus) ambarensis - (Schawaller 1982) (Scorpiones):
   [Referred to, Microtityus (Parvabsonus) ambarensis (Schawaller 1982), p.
   71]. 
   Microtityus (Parvabsonus) - Armas 1974 (Scorpiones): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 70]. 
   Microtityus (Parvabsonus) ambarensis - (Schawaller 1982) (Scorpiones):
   [Transferred from, Microtityus (Microtityus) ambarensis (Schawaller
   1982), p. 71]. 
   Microtityus barahona (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P. 73]. 
   Microtityus consuelo - Armas & Marcano Fondeur 1987 (Scorpiones):
   [Emended diagnosis, P. 78]. 
   Microtityus dominicanensis - Santiago-Blay 1985 (Scorpiones): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 80]. 
   Microtityus iviei - Armas 1999 (Scorpiones): [Emended diagnosis, P. 81].
   
   Microtityus lantiguai - Armas & Marcano 1992 (Scorpiones): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 82]. 
   Microtityus lourencoi (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P. 77].
   
   Microtityus paucidentatus - Armas & Marcano 1992 (Scorpiones): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 82]. 
   Microtityus prendinii (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P. 83].
   
   Microtityus reini (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P. 74]. 
   Microtityus rickyi - Kjellesvig-Waering 1966 (Scorpiones): [Removal from
   synonymy, Microtityus starri Lourenco & Huber 1999, p. 70]. 
   Microtityus solegladi (Scorpiones): [Sp nov, Dominican Republic, P. 71].
   
   Microtityus starri - Lourenco & Huber 1999 (Scorpiones): [Removal from
   synonymy, With Microtityus rickyi Kjellesvig-Waering 1966, p. 70]. 
   Microtityus virginiae - Armas 1999 (Scorpiones): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   86].

DT Article
TI Additions to the schizomids of central Cuba, with the description of
   four new species of Rowlandius Reddell & Cokendolpher 1995 (Schizomida:
   Hubbardiidae).
FT Adiciones a los esquizomidos de cuba central, con la descripcion de
   cuatro nuevos Rowlandius Reddell & Cokendolpher 1995 (schizomida:
   Hubbardiidae).
AU Teruel, Rolando (rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu) 
   de Armas, Luis F.
   Rodriguez, Tomas M.
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 97-112
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of schizomids belonging to the genus Rowlandius Reddell
   & Cokendolpher 1995, are herein described from central Cuba; also, the
   "biconourus" species-group is redefined on the basis of new taxonomic
   characters, and it is divided into two species-complexes. New records
   are given for five other species, with a description of the homomorphic
   male and female of Rowlandius florenciae Teruel 2003, the first records
   of Rowlandius cubanacan (Armas 1989) from Cienfuegos province and new
   findings of adult males of Stenochrus portoricensis Chamberlin 1922.
C1 Teruel, Rolando; Museo Hist Nat Tomas Romay, Ctr Oriental Ecosistemas &
   Biodiversidad BIOECO, Jose A Saco 601, Esquina A Barnada, Santiago De
   Cuba, 90100, Cuba, Cuba.
EM rteruel@bioeco.ciges.inf.cu
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; Central America; West Indies
DE Rowlandius [Cuba /  / New record; systematics]. 
   Rowlandius arenicola; Rowlandius candidae; Rowlandius guamuhaya;
   Rowlandius reconditus [Cuba /  / New species]. 
   Rowlandius cubanacan [Cuba / Cienfuegos / New record]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Schizomida
OR Rowlandius - Reddell & Cokendolpher 1995 (Schizomida): [New record]. 
   Rowlandius arenicola (Schizomida): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 104]. 
   Rowlandius biconourus species complex (Schizomida): [New species group,
   P. 98]. 
   Rowlandius biconourus species group (Schizomida): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   97]. 
   Rowlandius candidae (Schizomida): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 98]. 
   Rowlandius cubanacan (Schizomida): [New record]. 
   Rowlandius florenciae - Teruel 2003 (Schizomida): [Description,
   Homomorphic male & female, p. 108]. 
   Rowlandius guamuhaya (Schizomida): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 100]. 
   Rowlandius guamuhaya species complex (Schizomida): [New species group,
   P. 98].

PT J
AN ZOOR14912063566
DT Article
TI New solifuges from western Cuba (Solifugae: Ammotrechidae).
FT Nuevos solifugos de Cuba occidental (solifugae: Ammotrechidae).
AU de Armas, Luis F. (dearmas@ecologia.cu) 
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 119-124
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Both sexes of a new species of the genus Ammotrechella Roewer, 1934 from
   the westernmost part of Cuba (Guanahacabibes peninsula, Pinar del Rio
   province), as well as the male of a new species of Antillotrecha Armas,
   1994, from Canarreos archipelago (Isle of Young special municipality)
   are described. New localities are also recorded for Ammotrechella cubae
   (Lucas, 1835) and Ammotrecha enriquei Armas & Teruel, 2005. The presence
   of ctenidia in the males of all the Antillean Ammotrechidae is also
   established, a character previously misunderstood in these taxa.
C1 de Armas, Luis F.; Apartado Postal 4327, San Antonio De Los Banos,
   Artemisa, 32500, Cuba, Cuba.
EM dearmas@ecologia.cu
SC Zoology
SN 1576-9518
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America; West Indies
DE Ammotrechella cubae; Ammotrechella enrique [Cuba /  / New record]. 
   Ammotrechella elieri; Antillotrecha difficilis [Cuba /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Solpugida
OR Ammotrechella cubae (Solpugida): [New record]. 
   Ammotrechella elieri (Solpugida): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 120]. 
   Ammotrechella enrique (Solpugida): [New record]. 
   Antillotrecha difficilis (Solpugida): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 122].

DT Article
TI New oribatids (Acari, Oribatida) from Galicia (north-western Spain). A
   new subgenus, three new species and four first records from Spain.
FT Nuevos oribatidos (acari, Oribatida) de Galicia (noroeste de espana). Un
   subgenero nuevo, tres especies nuevas y cuatro primeras citas de espana.
AU Subias, Luis S. (subias@bio.ucm.es) 
   Shtanchaeva, Umukusum Ya.
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 125-130
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The 58 species of oribatid mites found in a soil sample taken in Galicia
   (north-western Spain) are studied. A new sub-genus, Subiasella
   (Paralalmoppia) n. subg., and three new species, Miracarus longisetosus
   n. sp., Subiasella (Paralalmoppia) barbulata n. sp. and Ocesobates
   galaicus n. sp., are described. The genus Tereticepheus S. & F. Bernini,
   1990 and the species Phthiracarus zicmani Balogh & Mahunka, 1983,
   Hermanniella grandis Sitnikova, 1973 and Tereticepheus undulatus
   (Willmann, 1939) are recorded for the first time from Spain. Also,
   Vaghia stupenda (Berlese, 1916) is recorded for the first time from
   Spain, and 19 species are recorded as new for the fauna of Galicia.
C1 Subias, Luis S.; Univ Complutense, Dept Zool, Madrid, E-28040, Spain,
   Spain.

TI Two new species of Diplocentrus Peters, 1861 (Scorpionidae:

   Diplocentrinae) de Guatemala.

   de Armas, Luis F.
SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 131-138
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Diplocentrus Peters, 1861 are described on
   the basis of three female specimens from the departments of Peten and
   Izabal, Guatemala. The species from Izabal resembles D. Iourencoi
   Stockwell, 1988, from the same range (Cordillera del Merendon) but in
   Honduran territory. The species from Peten resembles D. Maya Francke,
   1977, recorded from Belize (Toledo District) and north-eastern Guatemala
   (departments of Peten and Izabal).

TI A new genus of Hubbardiidae (Arachnida: Schizomida) from the Western

SO Revista Iberica de Aracnologia
VL 21
PS 139-143
PD 31 diciembre 2012
PY 2012
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus of hubbardiid schizomids is described from Risaralda
   department, in the Andean Western Range, Colombia. The male is similar
   to that of the genus Piaroa Villarreal, Giupponi & Tourinho, 2008, but
   the mobile finger of the chelicerae has a lamella ending in a large
   anteriorly directed accessory tooth; also, the female has spermathecae
   with two pairs of lobes, without a terminal bulb.

LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Three species of the genus Stilobezzia KIEFFER, 1911 are reported from
   Poland: Stilobezzia antennalis (COQUILLETT, 1901), Stilobezzia gracilis
   (HALIDAY, 1833) and Stilobezzia ochracea (WINNERTZ, 1852). They are
   diagnosed and illustrated. A key for the determination of males and
   females of Central European species is also provided. Stilobezzia
   virescens KIEFFER, 1919 is recognized as a new junior synonym of
   Stilobezzia flavirostris (WINNERTZ, 1852).

DT Article
TI Probable root structures and associated trace fossils from the Lower
   Pleistocene calcarenites of Favignana Island, southern Italy: dilemmas
   of interpretation.
AU Uchman, Alfred (alfred.uchman@uj.edu.pl) 
   Slaczka, Andrzej
   Renda, Pietro
SO Geological Quarterly
VL 56
IS 4
PS 745-756
PD December 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Uchman A., Slaczka A. and Renda P. (2012) Probable root structures and
   associated trace fossils from the Lower Pleistocene calcarenites of the
   Favignana Island, southern Italy: dilemmas of interpretation. Geol.
   Quart., 56(4): 745-756, doi: 10.7306/gq.1052 Two types of large,
   branched structures from the Lower Pleistocene (Calabrian) high-energy
   calcarenites of Favignana Island are described: Faviradixus robustus
   gen. et sp. nov. and Egadiradixus rectibrachiatus gen. et sp. nov. They
   may be interpreted as root structures of large plants, i.e., trees and
   trees or shrubs, respectively. The former taxon co-occurs with the
   marine animal trace fossils Ophiomorpha nodosa, Ophiomorpha isp.,
   Thalassinoides isp. and Beaconites isp. The interpretation as root
   structures although tentative is probable and can be related to short
   emergence episodes for the formation of E. rectibrachiatus or to longer
   emergence, responsible for the discontinuity at the base of the
   overlying Tyrrhenian deposits, for F. robustus. Calcified root mats of
   smaller plants associated with the Tyrrhenian or younger emergence
   surfaces are common. Alfred Uchman and Andrzej Slaczka, Institute of
   Geological Sciences, Jagiellonian University, Oleandry 2a, 30-063
   Krakow, Poland, e-mails: allfred.uchman@uj.edu.pl,
   andrzej.slaczka@uj.edu.pl; Pietro Renda, Dipartimento di Geologia,
   Universita di Palermo, Via Archirafi 20/22, 90100 Palermo, Italy,
   e-mail: renda@unipa.it (received: April 24, 2012; accepted: September
   12, 2012; first published online: November 5, 2012).
C1 Uchman, Alfred; Jagiellonian Univ, Inst Geol Sci, Oleandry 2A, Krakow,
   PL-30063, Poland, Poland.
EM alfred.uchman@uj.edu.pl
OI Uchman, Alfred/0000-0002-0591-777X
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1641-7291
BD Systematics; Ecology; Fossil traces; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Beaconites; Ophiomorpha; Thalassinoides [Fossil burrows /  /
   Co-occurrence with fossil tree root traces] [Mediterranean Sea / Italy,
   Sicily, Palermo / ] [Pleistocene / Lower Pleistocene / ]. 
ST Animalia
OR Beaconites (Animalia): [Fossil]. 
   Ophiomorpha (Animalia): [Fossil]. 
   Thalassinoides (Animalia): [Fossil].

DT Article
TI The Early Sarmatian bryozoan Celleporina medoborensis sp nov from the
   Medobory reefs of western Ukraine (Central Paratethys).
AU Hara, Urszula (urszula.hara@pgi.gov.pl) 
   Jasionowski, Marek
SO Geological Quarterly
VL 56
IS 4
PS 895-906
PD December 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Mound like, globular to hemispherical bryozoan colonies of Celleporina
   medoborensis sp. nov. are documented from the calcareous organodetrital,
   slightly marly facies of the Lower Sarmatian (Volhynian)
   serpulid-microbialite reefs, in the Polupanivka and Ditkivtsi quarries
   (Medobory Hills), located at the northeastern margin of the Carpathian
   Foreland Basin (Central Paratethys) in western Ukraine. The colonies of
   C. medoborensis are multilamellar, often with a subcircular hole and
   occur together with numerous cyclostome bryozoans (crisiids,
   tubuliporinids, branching colonies of entalophoroids) as well as
   schizoporellid and cryptosulid cheilostomes, accompanied by a few macro-
   and micro-fossil taxa. The combination of morphological characters such
   as: thick radial ribs in the pseudoporous, variably-shaped area of the
   ovicell, and one or two small adventitious oral, as well as large
   vicarious avicularia are the main characteristic features of species.
   The rich occurrence of the celleporiform colonies of C. nzedoborensis
   sp. nov. within the fine-grained calcareous sands of Polupanivka and
   Ditkivtsi suggests a shallow-water setting and high availability of soft
   substrates, probably dominated by calcareous algae upon which the
   bryozoans may have settled in the Medobory reef biota during the Early
   Sarmatian. Urszula Hara and Marek Jasionowski, Polish Geological
   Institute National Research Institute, Rakowiecka 4, 00-975 Warszawa,
   Poland, e-mails: urszula.hara@pgi.gov.pl, marek.jasionowski@pgi.gov.pl
   (received: May 17, 2012; accepted: October 26, 2012; published online:
   December 17, 2012).
C1 Hara, Urszula; Polish Geol Inst, Natl Res Inst, Rakowiecka 4, Warsaw,
   PL-00975, Poland, Poland.
EM urszula.hara@pgi.gov.pl
RI Jasionowski, Marek/Z-2956-2019
OI Jasionowski, Marek/0000-0003-3825-7859
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1641-7291
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Celleporina medoborensis [Ukraine /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ]. 
TN Bryozoans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Bryozoa
OR Celleporina medoborensis (Bryozoa): [Sp nov, Ukraine, Miocene, P. 898;
   Fossil].

DT Article
TI Discovery of Pectinocallimus (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae) from the Malay
   Peninsula, with Descriptions of Two New Species.
AU Niisato, Tatsuya
SO Elytra
VL 2
IS 2
PS 151-163
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Pectinocallimus NIISATO are described from
   the Malay Peninsula, based on three recently collected specimens
   including those of female. Until now, Pectinocallimus was known only
   from the single male holotype of the type-species, P. sericeus NIISATO,
   1989 from northern Borneo. The present discovery not only enlarges the
   genus with a new distribution in the Malay Peninsula but it facilitates
   also a first observation of female representative of the genus, and thus
   enables a better understanding of its systematic position. The genus is
   transferred from the Stenopterini to the Psebiini.
C1 Niisato, Tatsuya; Bioindicator Co Ltd, Shinjuku Ku, Rars Bldg,Hara Machi
   3-19, Tokyo, 1630053, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 0387-5733

   Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   systematics].

AB A new colydiine species, Microsicus constrictus, is described as the
   eighth representative of Microsicus from Japan. The new species is
   distinguishable from the other congeners by having the pronotum
   constricted at the posterior marginal parts and a pair of distinct
   concavities in the middle of pronotum.

DT Article
TI Description of Wilsonipsylla spinicoxa, New Genus and Species of Flea
   from Papua New Guinea and Review of the Suborder Pygiopsyllomorpha
   (Insecta: Siphonaptera).
AU Hastriter, Michael W. (michaelhastriter@comcast.net) 
SO Annals of Carnegie Museum
VL 81
IS 1
PS 19-32
PD 31 December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The infraorders Ceratophyllomorpha, Hystrichopsyllomorpha, Pulicomorpha,
   and Pygiopsyllomorpha erected by Medvedev (1998) have been elevated to
   subordinal entities. A systematic review of the suborder
   Pygiopsyllomorpha is provided. Three families (Lycopsyllidae,
   Pygiopsyllidae, and Stivaliidae) are recognized in the superfamily
   Pygiopsylloidea and a new subfamily, Farhangiinae is erected within
   Stivaliidae. A new genus and species, Wilsonipsylla spinicoxa, is
   described in the family Stivaliidae. A generic key is provided for the
   suborder Pygiopsyllomorpha. To date, 84 valid flea species are
   recognized in "New Guinea" (West Papua and Papua New Guinea) (to include
   W. spinicoxa), while the author is aware of more than 30 additional new
   species from multiple described genera.
C1 Hastriter, Michael W.; Monte L. Bean Life Science Museum, Brigham Young
   University, 290 MLBM, P.O. Box 20200, Provo, Utah 84602-0200, USA, USA.
EM michaelhastriter@comcast.net

SN 0097-4463; 1943-6300
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Taxonomy; Status; Key;
   Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts;
   Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia

   parasite species] [Papua New Guinea /  / New insect parasite species]. 
   Wilsonipsylla spinicoxa [Mammalian hosts / Paramelomys / New parasite
   species] [Papua New Guinea /  / New species from mammalian host]. 
TN Arthropods; Chordates; Insects; Invertebrates; Mammals; Rodents;

   Bradiopsyllini, p. 22]. 
   Bradiopsyllini - Wagner 1939 (Siphonaptera): [Raised to,
   Bradiopsyllinae, p. 22]. 
   Ceratophyllomorpha - Medvedev 1998 (Siphonaptera): [Status, Raised to
   suborder from infraorder, p. 19]. 
   Choristopsyllinae - Jordan & Rothschild 1922 (Siphonaptera): [Raised
   from, Choristopsyllini, p. 22]. 
   Choristopsyllini - Jordan & Rothschild 1922 (Siphonaptera): [Raised to,
   Choristopsyllinae, p. 22].

PT J
AN ZOOR15002008050
DT Article
TI Five New Species of Anillinus Casey from Alabama with a Key to the
   Alabama Species (Carabidae: Trechinae: Bembidiini).
AU Sokolov, Igor M. (igbembi@yahoo.com) 
SO Annals of Carnegie Museum
VL 81
IS 1
PS 61-71
PD 31 December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Five new species of anilline ground beetles are described from Alabama.
   Two species, Anillinus kingi, new species, and Anillinus davidsoni, new
   species, are litter and endogean species, respectively, from Blount
   Mountain Ridge (St. Clair County). Anillinus cavicola, new species, and
   Anillinus tombarri, new species, are troglobitic species from caves in
   Marshall County and the limestone belt of the Wills Creek Anticline (De
   Kalb County), respectively. Anillinus tombarri, at 3 mm length, is the
   largest representative of the genus known to science. Anillinus
   hirsutus, new species (Keel Mountain, Madison/Jackson Counties) is
   unique within the genus because of peculiarities of ventral vestiture
   not documented in other Anillinus species. Additional county records are
   given for Anillinus folkertsi Sokolov and Carlton, Anillinus steevesi
   Barr, and Anillinus valentinei (Jeannel). With these new discoveries,
   the known Alabama Anillinus fauna now includes eight species. All
   species are illustrated with images and drawings, and a key to the
   Alabama species is provided.
C1 Sokolov, Igor M.; St. Petersburg, Budapeshtskaya Str., 3/2-269, 192242,
   Russia, Russia.
EM igbembi@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 0097-4463; 1943-6300
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; USA
DE Anillinus [Alabama /  / Key to species]. 
   Anillinus cavicola; Anillinus davidsoni; Anillinus hirsutus; Anillinus
   kingi; Anillinus tombarri [Alabama /  / New species]. 
   Anillinus folkertsi [Alabama / Wilcox County / New record]. 
   Anillinus steevesi [Alabama / Blout, Colbert & Jackson counties / New
   record]. 
   Anillinus valentinei [Alabama / Jefferson County / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae

   Anillinus cavicola (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Alabama, P. 62]. 
   Anillinus davidsoni (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Alabama, P. 62]. 
   Anillinus folkertsi (Carabidae): [New record]. 
   Anillinus hirsutus (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Alabama, P. 64]. 
   Anillinus kingi (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Alabama, P. 66]. 
   Anillinus steevesi (Carabidae): [New record]. 
   Anillinus tombarri (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Alabama, P. 66]. 
   Anillinus valentinei (Carabidae): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15012074562
DT Article
TI Apristurus nakayai sp nov., a new species of deepwater catshark,
   (Chondrichthyes: Pentanchidae) from New Caledonia.
AU Iglesias, Samuel Paco (iglesias@mnhn.fr) 
SO Cybium
VL 36
IS 4
PS 511-519
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new species of deepwater catshark (Pentanchidae) is described based on
   a single adult male measuring 676 mm TL that was collected at a depth of
   953-1022 m on the Coriolis Bank off western New Caledonia in the
   southwestern Pacific Ocean. Within the genus Apristurus, the species
   belongs to the brunneus group whose members share a higher spiral valve
   count and the upper labial furrows are longer than the lower furrows.
   Apristurus nakayai sp. nov. differs from its congeners of the brunneus
   group through a combination of the following characters: shiny white
   iris on fresh specimen (unique among the genus); brownish black
   colouration; short distance from pectoral-fin tip to pelvic-fin origin,
   subequal to internarial width; cloaca located well anterior to the
   midpoint of the total length; pectoral fins large, width about 2.7 times
   pectoral fin tip to pelvic fin origin; long anal-fin base, longer than
   distance between dorsal fin insertions; first dorsal fin located well
   behind pelvic-fin insertion; first dorsal fin markedly smaller than
   second dorsal fin; very long caudal-fin terminal lobe, its length more
   than twice its height; no denticles in the mouth; very short pyloric
   stomach; Intestinal spiral valves 16; monospondylous vertebrae 36;
   precaudal diplospondylous vertebrae 37. DNA barcoding from the COI
   sequence reveal high genetic distances with its Australasian congeners.
C1 Iglesias, Samuel Paco; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Mil & Peuplements
   Aquat, Concarneau, F-29900, France, France.
EM iglesias@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0399-0974
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean

   species]. 
   Apristurus nakayai [South Pacific / New Caledonia / New species].

AN ZOOR15012074563
DT Article
TI Oxyeleotris colasi (Teleostei: Eleotridae), a new blind cave fish from
   Lengguru in West Papua, Indonesia.
AU Pouyaud, Laurent (laurent.pouyaud@ird.fr) 
   Kadarusman
   Hadiaty, Renny K.
   Slembrouck, Jacques
   Lemauk, Napoleon
   Kusumah, Ruby V.
   Keith, Philippe
SO Cybium
VL 36
IS 4
PS 521-529
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Oxyeleotris colasi is the first hypogean fish recorded from West Papua.
   The habitat consists of a freshwater pool in the cave of Jabuenggara
   located in the heart of Seraran anticline in the limestone karst of
   Lengguru. The new species is most closely related to the blind cave fish
   O. caeca described by Allen (1996) from eastern New Guinea. The two
   troglomorphic species are hypothesised to be related to O. fimbriata, an
   epigean freshwater gudgeon that ranges widely in New Guinea and northern
   Australia (Allen, 1996). Oxyeleotris colasi differs from its congeners
   by the absence of eyes, its skin and fins being totally depigmented, the
   presence of a well developed sensory papillae system partly consisting
   of low raised fleshy ridges on each side of the head, a reduced number
   of cephalic sensory pores, a reduced number of scales on head and body,
   a long head with a short snout length, a narrow mouth width and a long
   upper jaw length, body shape with a shallow anterior body depth and
   narrow body width, a long and deep caudal peduncle, long predorsal and
   prepectoral lengths, and a long pectoral fin.
C1 Pouyaud, Laurent; Inst Sci Evolut Montpellier, IRD CNRS UM2, 361 Rue
   Jean Francois Breton,BP 5095, Montpellier, F-34196, France, France.
EM laurent.pouyaud@ird.fr
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0399-0974
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Habitat; Freshwater habitat; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Oxyeleotris [Subterranean water / Cave habitat / Systematics] [Indonesia
   / West Papua / ]. 
   Oxyeleotris colasi [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Eleotridae
OR Oxyeleotris - Bleeker 1874 (Eleotridae). 
   Oxyeleotris colasi - Pouyaud, Kadarusman & Hadiaty 2014 (Eleotridae):
   [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 524].

AN ZOOR15012074568
DT Article
TI Osteology and relationships of Prognathoglossum kalassyi gen. and sp nov
   (Teleostei, Osteoglossiformes, Pantodontidae) from the marine Cenomanian
   (Upper Cretaceous) of En Nammoura (Lebanon).
AU Taverne, Louis (louis.taverne@gmail.com) 
   Capasso, Luigi
SO Cybium
VL 36
IS 4
PS 563-574
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The osteology of Prognathoglossum kalassyi, an osteoglossiform
   teleostean fish from the marine Cenomanian of En Nammoura in Lebanon, is
   described in details. This fish exhibits an important prognathism. The
   frontal is broad and short. The temporal fossa is located very laterally
   on the braincase. There is a small postfrontal behind the frontal. The
   parietal forms the dorsal border of the temporal fossa. The
   saccular-lagenar bulla is hypertrophied. This series of specialized
   characters is shared by the Recent osteoglossoid Pantodon and leads to
   range this Lebanese fossil genus within the family Pantodontidae.
C1 Taverne, Louis; Blvd Souverain 142 Box 8, Brussels, B-1170, Belgium,
   Belgium.
EM louis.taverne@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0399-0974

   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Prognathoglossum [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Prognathoglossum kalassyi [Lebanon /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ].

   Osteoglossiformes, Pantodontidae

   564].

   Type species Prognathoglossum kalassyi, p. 564, Cretaceous; Fossil].

AN ZOOR15204022716
DT Article
TI The Shallow-water Tanaidacea (Arthropoda: Malacostraca: Peracarida) of
   the Bass Strait, Victoria, Australia (other than the Tanaidae).
AU Blazewicz-Paszkowycz, Magdalena (magdab@biol.uni.lodz.pl) 
   Bamber, Roger N.
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 69
PS 1-235
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB All of the shallow-water tanaidacean taxa (except for species of the
   family Tanaidae) from material collected between 1964 and 1999 within
   the Bass Strait, Victoria, Australia, have been analyzed. The material
   had been collected predominantly by staff from the Museum Victoria,
   Melbourne. The species treated here are those occurring at depths <200
   m: substrata were predominantly sands. A total of 65 species in 43
   genera is discussed, of which 44 species, five genera and one subgenus
   are described as new, although two of the species are not named owing to
   inadequacy of the material. Only nine of the species are known from
   elsewhere in Australia. and none from outside Australia. In addition,
   after examination of more material of its type- (and only) species, the
   genus Annexos is synonymized with Apseudes, as is Xanthapseudes;
   Apseudes tuski is moved to Apseudopsis, subgenera of Bunakenia are
   rejected; the "tribes" Parapseudini and Pakistanapseudini are raised to
   Subfamily rank; Magniaculeusis synonymized with Saltipedis;
   intraspecific variation in Kalliapseudes obtusifrons is discussed; the
   genera of the Pagurapseudinae are resolved, and Pagurapseudes abrucei is
   transferred to Macrolabrum; the first male for the genus Bathytanais is
   described; the validity of the genus Ara phuroides is discussed, and A.
   lois returned to Araphura; Protanaissus makrotrichos, P alvesi and
   P.floridensis are moved to new genera; the family Tanaopsidae is erected
   to accommodate the genus Tanaopsis (at least).
C1 Blazewicz-Paszkowycz, Magdalena; Univ Lodz, Lab Polar Biol & Oceanobiol,
   Banacha 12-16, Lodz, PL-90237, Poland, Poland.
EM magdab@biol.uni.lodz.pl
RI Blazewicz, Magdalena/J-5175-2017
SC Zoology
SN 1447-2546; 1447-2554

   Diagnosis; Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Status; Key; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean

DT Article
TI Synidotea poorei, a new isopod from the fouling community in Singapore
   waters (Valvifera, Idoteidae).
AU Cai, Yixiong (caiyixiong@yahoo.com) 
   Teo, Serena L.M.
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 69
PS 237-243
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Synidotea poorei new species (Idoteidae) is described from fouling
   community on navigational buoys and jetties in Singapore waters. It
   belongs to the S. hirtipes species group. The new species is
   characterized by a smooth uropodal peduncle, sub-parallel pleotelson
   lateral margins and a moderately excavate pleotelson posterior margin.
   It represents a new record for the genus in Southeast Asia.
C1 Cai, Yixiong; Natl Pk Board, Natl Biodivers Ctr, 1 Cluny Rd, Singapore,
   259569, Singapore, Singapore.
EM caiyixiong@yahoo.com

PT J
AN ZOOR15204022718
DT Article
TI Two further species groups and new species among Australian
   Hydrobiosella Tillyard: new species from south-eastern Australia
   (Trichoptera: Philopotamidae).
AU Cartwright, David I. (cartwright@hotkey.net.au) 
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 69
PS 245-258
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Eleven philopotamid caddisfly species in the genus Hydrobiosella
   Tillyard are newly described from Australia, based on small differences
   in features of the male genitalia. These species are placed in two new
   species groups, one based on H. letti Korboot, the other on H.
   bandabanda sp. nov. The five species of the Hydrobiosella bandabanda
   group, all newly described here: H. bandabanda. H. jibboor, H. jirrima,
   H. tarrong and H. tiarka, share features of phallus with two or more
   embedded spines subapically and both preanal appendages and parameres
   absent. Females of four of these species are also figured in part. All
   five species are endemic to the eastern half of Victoria, mainland
   Australia. The H. letti species group comprises seven species:
   Hydrobiosella bifurca, H. bos, H. excilatas, H. fibra, H. incisura, H.
   letti Korboot and H. tenuitas, united in having features such as
   elongate, nearly straight parameres arising near middle to base of
   phallus, no obvious spines in phallus and presence of preanal
   appendages. Females of two of these species are also partly figured.
   These seven species are all are endemic to eastern coastal mainland
   Australia. from northeastern Victoria to eastern Queensland.
C1 Cartwright, David I.; 13 Brolga Crescent, Wandana Hts, Vic, 3216,
   Australia, Australia.
EM cartwright@hotkey.net.au
SC Zoology
SN 1447-2546; 1447-2554
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia

   Systematics]. 
   Hydrobiosella bandabanda; Hydrobiosella bos; Hydrobiosella jibboor;
   Hydrobiosella jirrima; Hydrobiosella tarrong; Hydrobiosella tiarka
   [Victoria /  / New species]. 
   Hydrobiosella bandabanda species group; Hydrobiosella letti species
   group [Australia /  / Key to species]. 
   Hydrobiosella bifarca; Hydrobiosella exilatis; Hydrobiosella fibra;
   Hydrobiosella incisura; Hydrobiosella tenuitas [Queensland /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Trichoptera
OR Hydrobiosella - Tillyard 1924 (Trichoptera): [Key to species groups,
   Australia, Males, p. 246; Key to species, Australia, Males, p. 246]. 
   Hydrobiosella bandabanda (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Victoria, P. 247]. 
   Hydrobiosella bandabanda group (Trichoptera): [New species group, P.
   246]. 
   Hydrobiosella bandabanda species group (Trichoptera): [Key to species,
   Australia, Males, p. 247]. 
   Hydrobiosella bifarca (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 255]. 
   Hydrobiosella bos (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Victoria, P. 257]. 
   Hydrobiosella exilatis (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 256]. 
   Hydrobiosella fibra (Trichoptera): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 255].

DT Article
TI Two new species of Photonectes (Teleostei: Stomiidae) from the
   Indo-Pacific, and a re-examination of P. achirus.
AU Flynn, A.J. (adrian.flynn@uqconnect.edu.au) 
   Klepadlo, C.
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 69
PS 259-267
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the mesopelagic fish genus Photonectes (family
   Stomiidae) from the Indo-Pacific are described. Both are referred to the
   subgenus Photonectes because they lack pectoral fins, have no fleshy
   tissue on their dorsal- and anal-fin rays, have a pelvic-fin insertion
   closer to the caudal-fin base than the snout, and have IP photophores
   located on the isthmus at a position midway along the mandible,
   posterior to the mandibular symphysis. Photonectes waitti sp. nov.,
   known from the tropical western and central Pacific Ocean. northwestern
   Coral Sea and north Indian Ocean, is most similar to P. coffea.
   differing from it by the number of PV photophores (24-25 vs. 29-31).
   gill filaments reduced (vs. greatly elongate). jaw teeth long and short
   canines (vs. short canines only), and barbel length less than (vs. equal
   to or greater than) head length. Photonectes paxtoni sp. nov., known
   from the tropical western Pacific Ocean, off Papua New Guinea, has a
   short barbel, less than head length. ending in a very large bulb without
   any terminal filaments or appendages, and different photophore numbers
   compared to other members of the subgenus: VAV 15-16 (vs. 10-15), AC 13
   (vs. 9-12), and IV 29 (vs. 30-46). Photonectes achirus is re-examined
   with respect to previously unreported dark pigment on the head.
C1 Flynn, A.J.; Univ Queensland, Sch Biomed Sci, St Lucia, Qld, 4071,
   Australia, Australia.
EM adrian.flynn@uqconnect.edu.au
SC Zoology
SN 1447-2546; 1447-2554
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Colour and luminescence;
   Colour; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; North Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean
DE Photonectes (Photonectes) paxtoni [South Pacific / Papua New Guinea /
   New species]. 
   Photonectes (Photonectes) waitti [Arabian Sea /  / New species] [North
   Pacific / Hawaii / ] [South Pacific / Australia / ] [ / Australia,
   Queensland / ]. 
   Photonectes achirus [Colour pigments / Pigmentation / Systematics]
   [Pacific Ocean /  / distribution]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Stomiiformes, Melanostomiidae
OR Photonectes (Melanostomiidae): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate
   taxa, P. 265]. 
   Photonectes (Photonectes) paxtoni (Melanostomiidae): [Sp nov, Papua New
   Guinea (marine), P. 265]. 
   Photonectes (Photonectes) waitti (Melanostomiidae): [Sp nov, Australia
   (marine), P. 260].

DT Article
TI The phyllophorid sea cucumbers of southern Australia (Echinodermata:
   Holothuroidea: Dendrochirotida: Phyllophoridae).
AU O'Loughlin, P. Mark (pmoloughlin@edmundrice.org) 
   Barmos, Shari
   VandenSpiegel, Didier
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 69
PS 269-308
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new monotypic Phyllophoridae (Phyllophorinae) genus Phyllostauros,
   with author O'Loughlin, is erected for Thyone vercoi Joshua and Creed.
   We raise Phyllophorella Heding and Panning (subgenus of Plzyllophorus
   Grube) to generic rank. The holotype and three paratypes of Phyllophorus
   ventripes Joshua and Creed are conspecific with Thyone vercoi Joshua and
   Creed. We make Phyllophorus ventripes Joshua and Creed a subjective
   junior synonym of Thyone vercoi Joshua and Creed. One paratype of
   Phyllophorus ventripes Joshua and Creed is conspecific with Phyllophorus
   thyonoides H. L. Clark. We reject the synonymy of Thyone okeni Bell with
   Thyone venusta Selenka. Twelve new species of Phyllophoridae are
   described for southern Australia, with author O'Loughlin: Lipotrapeza
   eichleri, Lipotrapeza litusi, Massinium melanieae, Massinium vimsi,
   Massinium ivatsonae, Phyllophorella notialis,Thyone flindersi,Thyone
   joshuai, Thyone kerkosa, Thyone spenceri, Thyme tottrvillei,
   Thyonidiella kungi. Phyllophoridae species reported previously for
   southern Australia are reviewed: Lipotrapeza ventripes (Joshua and
   Creed); Lipotrapeza vestiens (Joshua); Neothyonidium dearmattun (Dendy
   and Hindle); Phyrella thyonoides (H. L. Clark); Thyone nigra Joshua and
   Creed; Thyone okeni Bell; Thyone vercoi Joshua and Creed. Species
   Phyrella thyonoides (H. L. Clark) is re-assigned to genus Phyllophorella
   Heding and Panning. A key is provided for the southern Australian
   species of Phyllophoridae. We acknowledge the rejection for
   nomenclatorial purposes by the ICZN (Opinion 417) of the publication by
   Oken 1815, and hence the current invalid status of genus Thyone Oken. A
   petition has been sent to the ICZN for re-validation of Thyone Oken and
   we retain the use of Thyone Oken provisionally. The petition includes a
   similar request for re-validation of Psolus Oken.
C1 O'Loughlin, P. Mark; Museum Victoria, Marine Biol Sect, GPO Box 666,
   Melbourne, Vic, 3001, Australia, Australia.
EM pmoloughlin@edmundrice.org
SC Zoology
SN 1447-2546; 1447-2554
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Diagnosis;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; Key; Marine
   zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean

DT Article
TI Four new valviferan isopods from diverse tropical Australian habitats
   (Crustacea: Isopoda: Holognathidae and Idoteidae).
AU Poore, Gary C.B. (gpoore@museum.vic.gov.au) 
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 69
PS 327-340
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new isopods of the family Holognathidae are described from tropical
   Australia: Cleantioides carpentaria sp. nov. from shallow seagrass
   sediments in the Gulf of Carpentaria and an eastern Queensland port; and
   Zenobianopsis cidaris sp. nov. from 500 m depth in the Coral Sea. The
   latter is the third in its genus. Two new species of Synidotea
   (Idoteidae), S. innatans sp. nov. and S. karumba sp. nov. are described.
   Both are distinguished from others of the S. hirtipes-group of species,
   on the basis of subtle differences in colour and proportions of the body
   and limbs. The material of S. innatans was taken from flotsam in the
   Timor Sea and is potentially an obligate rafting species. Synidotea
   karumba is from shallow sedimentary environments in the Gulf of
   Carpentaria.
C1 Poore, Gary C.B.; Museum Victoria, GPO Box 666, Melbourne, Vic, 3001,
   Australia, Australia.
EM gpoore@museum.vic.gov.au
SC Zoology
SN 1447-2546; 1447-2554

   [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland / New species]. 
   Synidotea innatans [South Pacific / Australia / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Peracarida, Isopoda

   (marine), P. 328]. 
   Synidotea innatans (Isopoda): [Sp nov, Australia (marine), P. 332]. 
   Synidotea karumba (Isopoda): [Sp nov, Australia, Queensland (marine), P.
   336].

   (marine), P. 328].

DT Article
TI A review of giant roughies of the genus Hoplostethus (Beryciformes,
   Trachichthyidae), with descriptions of two new Australasian species.
AU Roberts, Clive D. (cliver@tepapa.govt.nz) 
   Gomon, Martin F.
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 69
PS 341-354
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Hoplostethus gigas McCulloch, 1914 and two previously unnamed species of
   the genus that reach a similarly 'giant' size are described. The
   redescription of H. gigas, which is confined in distribution to the
   southern coast of Australia, is based on specimens identified as
   comprising at least part of McCulloch's type series (one herein
   designated lectotype). together with subsequently collected material.
   The very similar H. melanopeza sp. nov., occurring in northern New
   Zealand and southeastern Australian waters, as well as seamounts in the
   intervening Tasman Sea, is distinguished by the distinctly black outer
   margins of fins in large adults and count of predorsal scales. The New
   Caledonian H. grandperrini sp. nov., known only from the two types,
   differs from previously described species in having the combination of
   17 or 18 pectoral fin rays, 13 or 14 abdominal scutes, 19 or 20 total
   gill rakers and a buccal cavity that is mostly pale, the only black
   pigmentation occurring posterior to the gill arches.
C1 Roberts, Clive D.; Museum New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, POB 467,
   Wellington, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM cliver@tepapa.govt.nz
SC Zoology
SN 1447-2546; 1447-2554
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Diagnosis;
   Description; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Hoplostethus grandperrini [South Pacific / New Caledonia / New species].
   
   Hoplostethus melanopeza [South Pacific / Australia, New South Wales /
   New species] [ / Australia, Victoria / ] [ / New Zealand / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Beryciformes, Trachichthyidae
OR Hoplostethus gigas - McCulloch 1914 (Trachichthyidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 342; Diagnostic characters, P. 343; Redescription, P.
   342]. 
   Hoplostethus grandperrini (Trachichthyidae): [Sp nov, New Caledonia
   (marine), P. 351]. 
   Hoplostethus melanopeza (Trachichthyidae): [Sp nov, New Zealand
   (marine), P. 346].

TI Some hydroids (Hydrozoa: Hydroidolina) from Dampier, Western Australia:
   annotated list with description of two new species.
AU Watson, Jeanette E. (hydroid@bigpond.com) 
SO Memoirs of Museum Victoria
VL 69
PS 355-363
PD Dec 31 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eleven species of hydroids including two new (Halecium corpulatum and
   Plumularia fragilia) from a depth of 50 m, 50 km north of Dampier,
   Western Australia are reported. The tropical hydroid fauna of Western
   Australia is poorly known; species recorded here show strong affinity
   with the Indonesian and Indo-Pacific region.

DT Article
TI A New Species of the Genus Nanhaipotamon (Decapoda Potamidae) from
   China.
AU Lin Guo-hua
   Cheng You-zhu (chengfz0591@163.com) 
   Chen Shao-hong
SO Chinese Journal of Parasitology and Parasitic Diseases
VL 30
IS 6
PS 434-437
PD December 30 2012
PY 2012
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Objective To investigate the species of freshwater crabs in Fujian
   Province, China. Methods Fresh-water crabs were collected in Pingtan
   County of Fujian Province. The morphological characteristics of the
   crabs and the habitats were observed. The crab morphology was described
   and crabs examined for the presence of Paragonimus metacerariae. Results
   A new species of freshwater crabs named Nanhaipotamon pingtanense sp.
   nov. was obtained, holotype(FJ6133,1):[male], carapace length 36.1 mm,
   breadth 46.8 mm, thickness 26.7 mm; allotype (FJ6133,2):[female],
   carapace length 33.9 mm, breadth 42.7 mm, thickness 25.4 mm, collected
   from Pingtan County (N 26[degree]52.958'; E 119[degree]58.722', and
   16-47 m above sea lever). Distal segment of the first male pleopod with
   squarish-rounded inner-distal angle, and the. comparatively stout
   out-distal angle's end narrowed. The out-lateral border sloped
   downwards, concave situated in the middle. The segment length is 2.3
   times as long as the subdistal segment. This species usually lived in
   the ditch and hid in mud hole. Paragonimus metacercariae were not found.
   Conclusion A new species of Nanhaipotamon collected from Pingtan County
   of Fujian Province were described, and named as Nanhaipotamon
   pingtanense.
C1 Cheng You-zhu; Fujian Ctr Dis Control & Prevent, Fuzhou, 350001, China,
   China.
EM chengfz0591@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7423
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Nanhaipotamon pingtanense [Fujian /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Nanhaipotamon (Brachyura): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate taxa,
   P. 436]. 
   Nanhaipotamon pingtanense (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Fujian, P. 435]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912063911
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14911051619
DT Article
TI A new species of Adelophryne (Anura: Eleutherodactylidae) from the
   Atlantic Forest, southeastern Brazil.
AU Santana, Diego Jose (santana_herpeto@yahoo.com.br) 
   da Fonseca, Emanuel Masiero
   Neves, Matheus de Oliveira
   Hoffmann de Carvalho, Rose Marie
SO Salamandra
VL 48
IS 4
PS 187-192
PD 30 December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB We describe a new species of Adelophryne from the Parque Municipal da
   Lajinha in Juiz de Fora, Minas Gerais state, southeast Brazil,
   constituting the southernmost record of the genus. Adelophryne
   meridionalis sp. n. is differentiated from other Adelophryne mainly by
   the presence of only two phalanges in finger IV, finger I being smaller
   than or equal to finger IV in dorsal view, and by having the terminal
   phalanges of its toes less developed. This new species is probably
   related to A. pachydactyla given that (1) both species have only two
   phalanges in Finger IV, and (2) a phylogenetic study demonstrated that
   A. pachydactyla belongs to a Southern Atlantic Forest clade along with
   at least three undescribed species.
C1 Santana, Diego Jose; Univ Fed Paraiba, Ctr Ciencias Exatas & Nat, Joao
   Pessoa, PB, BR-58059900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI Establishment of a new genus for Parastenocaris itica (Copepoda,
   Harpacticoida) from El Salvador, Central America, with discussion of the
   Parastenocaris fontinalis and P. proserpina groups.
AU Corgosinho, Paulo Henrique C. (pcorgo@gmail.com) 
   Arbizu, Pedro Martinez
   Previattelli, Daniel
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 102
IS 4
PS 401-411
PD Dec 30 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new genus of Parastenocarididae is described from the Neotropical
   region. Iticocaris gen. nov. is established to include Parastenocaris
   itica Noodt, 1962. Iticocaris gen. nov. is defined by the following
   characters: 1) male leg 3 with 2-segmented exopod; 2) first exopodal
   segment short and rectangular; 3) thumb hypertrophic, longer than the
   second exopodal segment and inserted on the distal edge of exopod
   segment 1, occupying the whole distal margin; 4) exopod 2 or apophysis
   strongly sclerotized, articulated with the exopod segment 1 on its inner
   margin and curved against the thumb, forming a strong forceps; 5) leg 4
   endopod without dimorphism in shape and size vs. minor dimorphism in
   ornamentation; 6) leg 5 with three setae and 7) lack of the
   anterolateral furcal seta II. The new genus is monotypic, represented by
   Iticocaris itica (Noodt, 1962) comb. nov., from El Salvador, Central
   America. A close relationship is hypothesized between I. itica and the
   genus Brasilibathynellocaris Jakobi, 1972, the males of which both share
   the forceps-like elongated apophysis.
C1 Corgosinho, Paulo Henrique C.; Int Ctr Educ Capac Bldg & Appl Res Water,
   Ctr Unesco HIDROEX, Av Mario Palmerio 1000, Frutal, MG, BR-38200000 BC,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM pcorgo@gmail.com
RI Previattelli, Daniel/S-2914-2017; Corgosinho, Paulo/C-1047-2015
OI Previattelli, Daniel/0000-0003-1432-5976; Corgosinho,
   Paulo/0000-0002-2851-6557; Martinez-Arbizu, Pedro/0000-0002-0891-1154

SN 0073-4721
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination; Taxonomy
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Harpacticoida

   Type species Parastenocaris itica Noodt 1962, p. 402]. 
   Iticocaris itica - (Noodt 1962) (Harpacticoida): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Parastenocaris, p. 401].

DT Article
TI A new species of Portanus (Hemiptera, Cicadellidae, Xestocephalinae)
   from Brazil.
AU de Carvalho, Adenomar N. (adenomarc@yahoo.com.br) 
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 102
IS 4
PS 423-425
PD Dec 30 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Portanus Ball, 1932 comprises 45 species that occur in Brazil, including
   Portanus felixi sp. nov. described and illustrated herein. The genus is
   close to Paraportanus Carvalho & Cavichioli, 2009 and can be
   distinguished from it by having a transversal groove on the basal third
   of the subgenital plates. The new species can be distinguished from the
   other species of the genus by the characters of male genitalia,
   especially by the pygofer with the apical process pointed, sclerotized
   and dorso-ventrally directed; and by the aedeagus with apodeme on the
   basal third.

DT Article
TI Taxonomic revision of doubtful Brazilian freshwater shrimp species of
   genus Macrobrachium (Decapoda, Palaemonidae).
AU Pileggi, Leonardo G. (lpileggi@gmail.com) 
   Mantelatto, Fernando L.
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 102
IS 4
PS 426-437
PD Dec 30 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 22
AB The freshwater prawns of the genus Macrobrachium Spence Bate, 1868 are
   widely distributed in rivers of tropical and subtropical regions and
   represent an interesting group with controversial taxonomy. The
   morphological characters traditionally used to separate species have
   shown a high intraspecific variation. Doubts about the status of M.
   birai Lobao, Melo & Fernandes, 1986, M. holthuisi Genofre & Lobao, 1978
   and M. petronioi Melo, Lobao & Fernandes, 1986 have been arisen due to
   the high resemblance of the former two species with M. olfersi
   (Wiegmann, 1836), and the latter one with M. potiuna (Muller, 1880).
   Therefore, we performed a detailed morphological analysis of these
   species, including new characters not usually used in the species
   recognition. The present results here with molecular data lead us to
   conclude that M. birai and M. holthuisi are junior synonyms of M.
   olfersi, and M. petronioi is a junior synonym of M. potiuna. Considering
   these synonymies, 17 valid species are now reported for the Brazilian
   territory.
C1 Pileggi, Leonardo G.; USP, FFCLRP, Av Bandeirantes 3900, Ribeirao Preto,
   SP, BR-14040901 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM lpileggi@gmail.com

OI Mantelatto, Fernando/0000-0002-8497-187X; Mantelatto, Fernando
   L/0000-0002-8497-187X
SC Zoology
SN 0073-4721
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Natantia
OR Macrobrachium - Bate 1868 (Natantia): [Revision, Doubtful species, p.
   426]. 
   Macrobrachium olfersi - (Wiegmann 1836) (Natantia): [Description, P.
   427; Syn nov, Macrobrachium birai Lobao, Melo & Fernandes 1986, p. 427;
   Syn nov, Macrobrachium holthuisi Genofre & Lobao 1978, p. 427]. 
   Macrobrachium potiuna - Mueller 1880 (Natantia): [Syn nov, Macrobrachium
   petronioi Melo, Lobao & Fernandes 1986, p. 431]. 
   Macrobrachium potuina - (Muller 1880) (Natantia): [Description, P. 431].

PT J
AN ZOOR14907025613
DT Article
TI Invasive, non-indigenous corals in a tropical rocky shore environment:
   No evidence for generalist predation.
AU Moreira, Thaise S.G.
   Creed, Joel C. (jcreed@uerj.br) 
SO Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology
VL 438
PS 7-13
PD Dec 30 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 123
AB The biological invasion of rocky shore communities modifies species
   composition and the interaction between community elements. Two species,
   Tubastraea coccinea Lesson, 1829 and Tubastraea tagusensis Wells, 1982
   have been identified as non-indigenous and invasive to the tropical
   rocky shores of southeast Brazil. The aim of the current study was to
   investigate predator-prey interactions between a guild of native
   potential generalist predators and the non-indigenous corals using total
   exclusion and partial cages versus controls on a tropical rocky shore in
   the southwest Atlantic. Despite generalist predators being present in
   natural densities on the experimental system and substantial settlement
   occurring during the 2 year study (average density of Tubastraea spp.
   was 11.29 ind. 240 cm-2) no significant differences were found in
   density or size of corals between treatments. Dominant groups in the
   accompanying biological community (ABC) were encrusting calcareous and
   turf algae, the sponge Iotrochota sp. and barnacles but ABC height and
   biomass and sediment mass did not differ between treatments. Due to
   transport and invasion of new communities these corals are thought to
   have escaped from predation despite a diverse suite of native potential
   generalist predators. Both corals have been shown to possess bioactive
   chemicals which predatory fish avoid and this would seem to be the
   mechanism of predator avoidance. The successful invasion by Tubastraea
   spp. in the southwest Atlantic is at least in part due to highly reduced
   (or nil) predation compared to the native range. [copyright] 2012
   Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Creed, Joel C.; Univ Estado Rio de Janeiro, Dept Ecol, PHLC Sala 220,Rua
   Sao Francisco Xavier 524, Rio De Janeiro, RJ, BR-20559900 BC, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM jcreed@uerj.br
RI Creed, Joel J/C-4764-2013
OI Creed, Joel J/0000-0002-1722-0806
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0022-0981
BD Ecology; Habitat; Marine habitat; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Tubastraea coccinea; Tubastraea tagusensis [Predators / Predator prey
   interaction / Exotic species] [Marine shore habitat / Tropical rocky
   shore habitat / ] [South Atlantic / Brazil, Ilha Grande Bay / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Scleractinia
OR Tubastraea coccinea (Scleractinia): [Prey]. 
   Tubastraea tagusensis (Scleractinia): [Prey]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14907025613
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14907025618
DT Article
TI Parasite-induced behavioural changes to the trade-off between foraging
   and predator evasion in a marine snail.
AU Kamiya, Tsukushi (kamts408@student.otago.ac.nz) 
   Poulin, Robert
SO Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology
VL 438
PS 61-67
PD Dec 30 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 116
AB Trophic interactions in ecological communities not only affect
   consumer-resource densities, but also induce phenotypic responses that
   can ripple through a food web to influence prey resources, competitors
   and other predators (i.e. trait-mediated interactions). Predators affect
   short-term trade-off decisions in prey species through behavioural
   alterations, yet the role of parasites in the context of trait-mediated
   interactions is rarely discussed, despite our extensive knowledge of
   parasite-induced behavioural alterations. Adding parasites to the
   picture, the foraging-predation trade-off presents an interesting case
   where the effects of predator- and parasite-induced behavioural
   responses occur in conjunction. Empirical studies on the effect of
   parasites on trait-mediated anti-predator responses are still scarce,
   especially in marine systems. Our experiments used marine mud snails,
   Zeacumantus subcarinatus (Batillariidae), infected with the trematode
   parasites Maritrema novaezealandensis and Philophthalmus sp. to
   investigate the effects of trematode-induced behavioural alterations on
   the trade-off between food acquisition and predator avoidance in the
   presence of a range of predation cues. We found that the time taken to
   initiate anti-predator responses was overall significantly shorter in M.
   novaezealandensis-infected snails than in uninfected snails, while it
   was significantly longer for Philophthalmus-infected snails. In the
   simultaneous presence of odours from an injured conspecific and a crab
   predator, however, the reaction time between uninfected and M.
   novaezealandensis-infected snails did not differ while
   Philophthalmus-infected snails were still markedly slower than the
   former groups. Our results demonstrate species-specific parasite-induced
   behavioural changes in the presence of imminent predation risk. However,
   effects of the trematodes on overall feeding and fleeing times were not
   detected in our experiments; thus, the net effect of parasitism on the
   foraging-predation trade-off remains unknown. (C) 2012 Elsevier B.V. All
   rights reserved.
C1 Kamiya, Tsukushi; Univ Otago, Dept Zool, POB 56, Dunedin, New Zealand,
   New Zealand.
EM kamts408@student.otago.ac.nz
RI Poulin, Robert/C-3117-2008; Kamiya, Tsukushi/AAX-6412-2020
OI Poulin, Robert/0000-0003-1390-1206; Kamiya, Tsukushi/0000-0002-9020-6699
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Environmental Sciences
   &Ecology
SN 0022-0981
BD Nutrition; Digestion; Defaecation; Feeding behaviour; Parasites diseases
   and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Ecology; Marine
   zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Maritrema novaezealandensis; Philophthalmus [Molluscan hosts /
   Zeacumantus subcarinatus / Parasite-induced behavioural changes] [South
   Pacific / New Zealand, Lower Portobello Bay / ]. 
   Zeacumantus subcarinatus [Faeces /  / ] [Foraging /  / ] [Digenean
   parasites / Maritrema novaezealandensis / ] [ / Philophthalmus / ]
   [Predators / Predation trade-off / ] [South Pacific / New Zealand, Lower
   Portobello Bay / ].

TI A new Trypetimorpha species from Australia and new data to the knowledge
   of the genus (Homoptera, Archaeorhyncha: Tropiduchidae).
AU Orosz, A. (orosz@nhmus.hu) 
SO Folia Entomologica Hungarica
VL 73
PS 15-27
PD Dec 30 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New data are presented on the planthopper fauna of Australia, Taiwan and
   Thailand on the basis of the Oriental and Pacific planthoppers deposited
   in the Hungarian Natural History Museum. Hitherto 8 valid species have
   been described from the genus Trypetimorpha A. COSTA, 1862; the material
   investigated in the present paper represents six species, and anew
   species is described from Australia. Figures on habitus and tegmen of a
   T. pilosa HORVATH, 1907 syntype is given for the first time with
   additional new figure on its genitalia. T.japonica ISHIHARA, 1954 and
   T.sizhengi HUANG et BOURGOIN, 1993 are new to the fauna of Thailand.
   With 28 figures and one table.

   surveys) on the distribution of 239 species of Lycaenidae (Lepidoptera:
   Rhopalocera) in Ghana are presented as the first results of the
   long-term research project "Butterfly and Moth Inventory and Prime
   Butterfly Areas in Ghana". Aslauga cf. prouvosti, Pen tila condamini

   1903), and Geritola albomaculata (BETHUNE-BAKER, 1903) are recorded as
   new in the Lepidoptera fauna of Ghana. Many records of other species are
   of biogeographical importance. With one figure.

DT Article
TI The fossil record and phylogeography of the family Cerionidae
   (Gastropoda: Pulmonata), with the description of a new species from the
   Pleistocene of Florida.
AU Harasewych, M.G. (Harasewych@si.edu) 
SO Nautilus
VL 126
IS 4
PS 119-126
PD Dec 28 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Cerion petuchi, new species, the first record of the genus from the
   Pleistocene of Florida, is described from Loxahatchee, Florida, from
   deposits of the Loxahatchee Member of the Bermont Formation (Aftonian
   Pleistocene). This new species is more similar to Cerion agassizii from
   the Pleistocene of the Great Bahamas Bank, and to the Recent Cerion
   incanum saccharimeta, from the Florida Keys, than to either of the
   species from the Late Oligocene-Early Miocene Ballast Point Si lex Beds
   of Tampa, Florida. Data on the geographic distribution and geological
   age of all known cerionids is compiled and, together with models of the
   geologic and tectonic history of the Caribbean region, used to construct
   a hypothesis of the origins, ages, and relationships among the various
   lineages within the family since the Upper Cretaceous. The early
   distribution of the family was governed primarily by overland dispersal
   and vicariance. It is suggested that the significant proliferation of
   diversity that began during the Pleistocene is due to the increased
   prevalence of stochastic dispersal of small propagules (either by
   rafting or hurricane-born) among the islands of the Cuban and Bahamian
   archipelagos. Sea level changes caused by Pleistocene glaciations
   amplified diversity by repeatedly and sequentially recombining /
   hybridizing and isolating neighboring populations. Amplification of
   diversity would have been greatest on the Great Bahama Bank, as it had
   the highest number of islands that were isolated during interglacial
   periods and conjoined during glaciations.
C1 Harasewych, M.G.; Smithsonian Inst, Natl Museum Nat Hist, MRC 163,POB
   37012, Washington, DC, 20013, USA, USA.
EM Harasewych@si.edu
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0028-1344
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time periods;
   Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Cerion [Florida /  / new record] [Pleistocene /  / ]. 
   Cerion petuchi [Florida /  / new species] [Pleistocene /  / ]. 
   Cerionidae [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / fossil & extant taxa]
   [Zoogeography /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs

   Orthalicoidea

   Cerion petuchi (Orthalicoidea): [Sp nov, Florida, Pleistocene, P. 120;
   Fossil]. 
   Cerionidae (Orthalicoidea).

TI A new species of Fusivoluta Martens, 1902 (Gastropoda: Volutidae) from
   Mozambique.
AU Bail, Patrice (pat.bail@orange.fr) 
   Puillandre, Nicolas
SO Nautilus
VL 126
IS 4
PS 127-135
PD Dec 28 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB During a recent expedition to Mozambique, several specimens attributed
   to the genus Fusivoluta von Martens, 1902 were collected between 1100
   and 1820 m deep. Among them, a new species has been found and is here
   described and compared with the other East African Fusivoluta. Several
   live-collected specimens, belonging to the newly described species and
   to Fusivoluta clarkei Rehder, 1969 were sequenced for a nuclear gene
   (28S), revealing fixed differences between the two species.

DT Article
TI A new species of Mysella from Patagonia (Bivalvia: Galeommatoidea).
AU Ituarte, Cristian (ituarte@macn.gov.ar) 
   Pablo Martin, Juan
   Zelaya, Diego G.
SO Nautilus
VL 126
IS 4
PS 136-142
PD Dec 28 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The poorly known diversity of the genus Mysella in the southwestern
   Atlantic is improved with the description of a new species from San
   Julian Bay, Santa Cruz Province, Argentina. Mysella patagona new species
   is characterized by the relative large, strikingly subquadrate, slightly
   inequilateral and flat shell; a cleft hinge plate, with two widely
   diverging teeth in the right valve, and a cylindrical internal ligament
   located in a deep ligamental pit. From the anatomical point of view, M.
   patagona new species is characterized by the presence of inner and outer
   demibranchs, with very few interlamellar junctions. The marked
   subquadrate shell outline easily distinguishes M. patagona from any
   other Mysella species currently known from the Magellan Region.
C1 Ituarte, Cristian; Museo Argentino Ciencias Nat, Av Angel Gallardo
   470,CI405DJR, Buenos Aires, DF, Argentina, Argentina.
EM ituarte@macn.gov.ar
SC Zoology
SN 0028-1344
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Mysella patagona [South Atlantic / Argentina / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Heterodonta, Veneroida, Galeommatoidea
OR Mysella patagona (Galeommatoidea): [Sp nov, Argentina (marine), P. 138].
   
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14910042591
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15507039219
DT Article
TI On the Staphylinidae of Socotra Island, Yemen (Insecta: Coleoptera).
AU Assing, V. (vassing.hann@t-online.de) 
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 44
IS 2
PS 973-986
PD 28 Dezember 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A study of material of Staphylinidae collected in the Yemenite island
   Socotra and in the south of mainland Yemen yielded approximately 50
   species, 27 of which were identified at species level. Six of them, all
   from Socotra, are described and illustrated: Octavius curtissimus
   nov.sp., Edaphus hlavaci nov.sp., E. socotranus nov.sp., Pinophilinus
   socotranus nov.sp., Pseudomedon macer nov.sp., and Brachida socotrana
   nov.sp. Of the previously described species, eight species are reported
   from Socotra for the first time, nine species represent new country
   records for Yemen, and one Afrotropical species is reported from the
   Palaearctic region for the first time.
C1 Assing, V.; Gabelsbergerstr 2, Hannover, D-30163, Germany, Germany.
EM vassing.hann@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 0253-116X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia

TI A new species of Tectusa from the Alpi Orobie, Italy (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae: Aleocharinae).
AU Assing, V. (vassing.hann@t-online.de) 
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 44
IS 2
PS 987-991
PD 28 Dezember 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Tectusa orobiana nov.sp. (N-Italy: Lombardia: Alpi Orobie) is described,
   illustrated, and distinguished from similar and geographically close
   congeners. The species is the fifth representative of the genus known
   from Italy.

U2 0
AB Himalagria utriculata nov.sp. (central Nepal: Kali Gandaki valley) is
   described, illustrated, and distinguished from H. hetzeli ASSING 2005,
   the type species of Himalagria ASSING 2005. An additional undescribed
