DT Article
TI Carajathemis simone, new genus and species from Brazil (Odonata:
   Libellulidae).
AU Machado, Angelo B.M. (angelo@icb.ufmg.br) 
SO Anais da Academia Brasileira de Ciencias
VL 84
IS 4
PS 1039-1049
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Carajathemis simone n. gen., n.sp. from the state of Para, Brazil, is
   described and illustrated based on 22 specimens collected in a "canga"
   (laterite) lake within the forest at the Flona de Carajas, Parauapebas
   Municipality. The new libellulid genus fits in the subfamily Sympetrinae
   and the male keys out to Erythemis in Garrison et al. (2006). The new
   taxon has a combination of characters that makes it different from all
   genera of Sympetrinae including Erythemis. The species is remarkable by
   its large size, pleural striping and especially by the complex and
   strongly dimorphic leg armature. It seems to be restricted to shallow,
   rainfall-dependent, iron-rich lakes.

DT Article
TI Amphibian Pathogens in Southeast Asian Frog Trade.
AU Gilbert, Martin (mgilbert@wcs.org) 
   Bickford, David
   Clark, Leanne
   Johnson, Arlyne
   Joyner, Priscilla H.
   Keatts, Lucy Ogg
   Khammavong, Kongsy
   Long Nguyen Van
   Newton, Alisa
   Seow, Tiffany P.W.
   Roberton, Scott
   Silithammavong, Soubanh
   Singhalath, Sinpakhone
   Yang, Angela
   Seimon, Tracie A.
SO EcoHealth
VL 9
IS 4
PS 386-398
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 51
AB Amphibian trade is known to facilitate the geographic spread of
   pathogens. Here we assess the health of amphibians traded in Southeast
   Asia for food or as pets, focusing on Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis
   (Bd), ranavirus and general clinical condition. Samples were collected
   from 2,389 individual animals at 51 sites in Lao PDR, Cambodia, Vietnam
   and Singapore for Bd screening, and 74 animals in Cambodia and Vietnam
   for ranavirus screening. Bd was found in one frog (n = 347) in Cambodia
   and 13 in Singapore (n = 419). No Bd was found in Lao PDR (n = 1,126) or
   Vietnam (n = 497), and no ranavirus was found in Cambodia (n = 70) or
   Vietnam (n = 4). Mild to severe dermatological lesions were observed in
   all East Asian bullfrogs Hoplobatrachus rugolosus (n = 497) sampled in
   farms in Vietnam. Histologic lesions consistent with sepsis were found
   within the lesions of three frogs and bacterial sepsis in two (n = 4);
   one had Gram-negative bacilli and one had acid-fast organisms consistent
   with mycobacterium sp. These results confirm that Bd is currently rare
   in amphibian trade in Southeast Asia. The presence of
   Mycobacterium-associated disease in farmed H. rugolosus is a cause for
   concern, as it may have public health implications and indicates the
   need for improved biosecurity in amphibian farming and trade.
C1 Gilbert, Martin; Wildlife Conservat Soc, 2300 Southern Blvd, Bronx, NY,
   10460, USA, USA.
EM mgilbert@wcs.org
RI Bickford, David/A-5306-2011
OI Bickford, David/0000-0003-1478-3387
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Physiology; Infectious
   Diseases; Mycology
BD Animals and man; Disturbance by man; Commercial activities; Whole animal
   physiology; Parasites diseases and disorders; Diseases and disorders;
   Microbial diseases; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Bufonidae; Megophryidae; Microhylidae; Pipidae; Ranidae [Trade in
   animals /  / ] [Physiological condition / Health / ] [Bacterial diseases
   / Mycobacterium / ] [Fungal diseases / Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis /
   ] [Viral diseases / Ranavirus / ] [Asia / Cambodia, Laos, Singapore &
   Vietnam / ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura

DT Article
TI First Amphilestid from South America: A Molariform from the Jurassic
   Caadn Asfalto Formation, Patagonia, Argentina.
AU Gaetano, Leandro C.
   Rougier, Guillermo W. (lcgaetano@gl.fcen.uba.ar) 
SO Journal of Mammalian Evolution
VL 19
IS 4
PS 235-248
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB We report here the first amphilestid triconodont from the Jurassic of
   South America. The specimen, a single isolated molariform, was found at
   the Queso Rallado locality from where a growing mammalian fauna is known
   (including a triconodontid, two australosphenidans, and an as yet
   undescribed allotherian). The specimen, interpreted as a left lower
   tooth, presents five mesiodistally aligned, fairly symmetrical cusps,
   and is recognized as the type of a new taxon, Condorodon spanios. The
   phylogenetic analysis recovers Condorodon as a member of the clade
   Amphilestheria, closely related to Tendagurodon janenschi, an
   amphilestid triconodont from the Late Jurassic of Tanzania. Condorodon
   spanios is only distantly related to Argentoconodon fariasorum, the
   other triconodont known from Queso Rallado quarry. The phylogenetic
   position of Condorodon spanios points to the origin and diversification
   of amphilestherians during the Early Jurassic in a paleogeographical
   setting that allowed wide dispersion of these forms and argues, at least
   from the mammalian evidence, against a highly provincialized Pangaea.
   Some differences are however established between the filial
   western/eastern Gondwanan masses and their respective faunas.
C1 Rougier, Guillermo W.; Univ Louisville, Dept Anat Sci & Neurobiol, 500 S
   Preston St, Louisville, KY, 40292, USA, USA.
EM lcgaetano@gl.fcen.uba.ar
SC Zoology
SN 1064-7554
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Amphilestidae [South America /  / new record] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
   Condorodon [Jurassic /  / New genus]. 
   Condorodon spanios [Argentina /  / new species] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Triconodonta
OR Amphilestidae (Triconodonta): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Condorodon (Triconodonta): [Gen nov, Of family Amphilestidae, Type
   species Condorodon spanios, p. 236, Jurassic; Fossil]. 
   Condorodon spanios (Triconodonta): [Sp nov, Argentina, Jurassic, P. 236;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14910042290

PT J
AN ZOOR14910042364
DT Article
TI Systematics and phylogenetic species delimitation within Polinices s.l.
   (Caenogastropoda: Naticidae) based on molecular data and shell
   morphology.
AU Huelsken, Thomas (t.huelsken@gmail.com) 
   Tapken, Daniel
   Dahlmann, Tim
   Waegele, Heike
   Riginos, Cynthia
   Hollmann, Michael
SO Organisms Diversity & Evolution
VL 12
IS 4
PS 349-375
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 15
AB Here, we present the first phylogenetic analysis of a group of species
   taxonomically assigned to Polinices sensu latu (Naticidae, Gastropoda)
   based on molecular data sets. Polinices s.l. represents a speciose group
   of the infaunal gastropod family Naticidae, including species that have
   often been assigned to subgenera of Polinices (e.g. P. (Neverita), P.
   (Euspira), P. (Conuber) and P. (Mammilla)) based on conchological data.
   The results of our molecular phylogenetic analysis confirm the validity
   of five genera, Conuber, Polinices, Mammilla, Euspira and Neverita,
   including four that have been used previously mainly as subgenera of
   Polinices s.l. Our results furthermore indicate a close relationship of
   members of the Polinicinae to Sinum-a genus traditionally placed in the
   naticid subfamily Sininae. We furthermore present conchological analyses
   to determine the validity of shell characters used traditionally in
   species designation in the genus Polinices. Our data reveal several
   characters (e.g. protoconch, operculum colour, parietal callus) to be
   informative, while many characters show a high degree of homoplasy (e.g.
   umbilicus, shell form). Among the species arranged in the genus
   Polinices s.s., four conchologically very similar taxa often subsumed
   under the common Indo-Pacific species P. mammilla are separated
   distinctly in phylogenetic analyses. Despite their striking
   conchological similarities, none of these four taxa are related directly
   to each other. Additional conchological analyses of available
   name-bearing type specimens and type figures reveal the four
   "mammilla"-like white Polinices species to include true P. mammilla and
   three additional species, which could be assigned to P. constanti
   (replacement name for P. dubius), P. jukesii and possibly P.
   tawhitirahia, based on protoconch and operculum characteristics.
C1 Huelsken, Thomas; Univ Queensland, Sch Biol Sci, Brisbane, Qld, 4072,
   Australia, Australia.
EM t.huelsken@gmail.com
RI Riginos, Cynthia/G-3320-2010; Dahlmann, Tim/AAS-6500-2020
OI Riginos, Cynthia/0000-0002-5485-4197; Tapken,
   Daniel/0000-0002-0166-0751; Wagele, Heike/0000-0001-6899-0336
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1439-6092
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Available name; Taxonomy; Skeletal and
   supporting structures; Shell; Genetics; Evolution
DE Polinices [Shell morphology /  / systematics] [Molecular genetics /  / ]
   [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda,
   Naticoidea
OR Conuber - Finlay & Marwick 1937 (Naticoidea): [Status, P. 372]. 
   Euspira - Sowerby J. 1837 (Naticoidea): [Status, P. 373]. 
   Mammilla - Schuhmacher 1817 (Naticoidea): [Status, P. 371]. 
   Neverita - Risso 1826 (Naticoidea): [Status, P. 372]. 
   Polinices - Montfort 1810 (Naticoidea). 
   Polinices constanti - Huelsken & Hollmann 2012 (Naticoidea): [Nom nov,
   For Polinices dubius (Recluz 1844), p. 368]. 
   Polinices dubius - (Recluz 1844) (Naticoidea): [Preoccupied name
   replaced by, Polinices constanti Huelsken & Hollmann 2012, p. 368]. 
   Sinum - Roding 1798 (Naticoidea): [Taxonomic position, P. 373]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14910042364

PT J
AN ZOOR14910042368
DT Article
TI The enigmatic Alpine opilionid Saccarella schilleri gen. n., sp. n.
   (Arachnida: Nemastomatidae) - isolated systematic placement inferred
   from comparative genital morphology.
AU Schoenhofer, Axel L. (Axel.Schoenhofer@uni-mainz.de) 
   Martens, Jochen
SO Organisms Diversity & Evolution
VL 12
IS 4
PS 409-419
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 15
AB In Opiliones, male genital morphology plays a key role in systematics
   and understanding the evolution of the group because functional
   modifications often outline higher taxonomic levels. In Nemastomatidae,
   different lateral stabilizing structures on the penial truncus cane
   developed independently. These wing-like protuberances serve as anchor
   points for two muscular tendons and are interpreted traditionally as
   generic characters. A newly discovered species from Monte Saccarello in
   the Ligurian Alps of North-western Italy is unique in providing anchor
   points as stabilizing parts of the distal truncus cane below the glans
   by short and narrow lateral folds. To place this unusual species within
   the Nemastomatidae one must re-evaluate the usefulness of male genital
   morphological and other characters used in the systematics of the
   family. The resulting phylogenetic framework is supplemented with
   available molecular genetic data. Based on both datasets, the creation
   of a new genus seems justified. Saccarella schilleri gen. n. sp. n. is
   subsequently described and further defined. The endemism and
   biogeography of the harvestmen fauna in the South-western Alps are
   discussed with respect to this enigmatic genus.
C1 Schoenhofer, Axel L.; San Diego State Univ, Dept Biol, San Diego, CA,
   92182, USA, USA.
EM Axel.Schoenhofer@uni-mainz.de
SC Zoology
SN 1439-6092
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Saccarella schilleri [Italy /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Opiliones
OR Saccarella (Opiliones): [Gen nov, Of family Nemastomatidae, Type species
   Saccarella schilleri, p. 412]. 
   Saccarella schilleri (Opiliones): [Sp nov, Italy, P. 412].

TI A new species of Lepidoptera from the National Park of Casentine Forests
   (Tuscan-Romagna Apennine): Dahlica casentinensis n. sp.
FT Rinvenuta nel Parco Nazionale delle Foreste Casentinesi (Appennino
   Tosco-Romagnolo) una nuova specie di Lepidottero: Dahlica casentinensis
   n. sp. (Insecta Lepidoptera Psychidae).
AU Bertaccini, Edgardo (valentinabertaccini@aliceposta.it) 
SO Quaderno di Studi e Notizie di Storia Naturale della Romagna
VL 36
PS 61-78
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB (A new species of Lepidoptera from the National Park of Casentine
   Forests (Tuscan-Romagna Apennine): Dahlica casentinensis n. sp.) The new
   species Dahlica casentinensis n. sp. (Lepidoptera: Psychidae) is
   described from the National Park of Casentine Forests, in Tuscan-Romagna
   Apennine. The new species is thoroughly studied and compared with the
   most similar congeners; the principal features are summarized in a
   table. The specific rank is also confirmed by molecular investigation
   (mtDNA).

DT Article
TI A new species from Turkey of the genus Tenuicollis Marseul, 1879
   (Insecta Coleoptera Anthicidae).
FT Una nuova specie della Turchia del genere Tenuicollis Marseul, 1879
   (Insecta Coleoptera Anthicidae).
AU Degiovanni, Augusto (gusto.a@libero.it) 
SO Quaderno di Studi e Notizie di Storia Naturale della Romagna
VL 36
PS 97-103
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB (A new species from Turkey of the genus Tenuicollis Marseul, 1879
   (Insecta Coleoptera Anthicidae)) Tenuicollis angelinii n. sp. is
   described from the province of cankiri in central-northern Turkey. This
   species is distinguishable at first sight from all congeners by the
   peculiar length of head (about 2.7 times longer than wide). It is a
   medium-size species (2.9 mm in lenght), deep black colour, with
   olivaceous reflections on elytra. All legs entirely black, except the
   proximal half of tibiae yellowish-brown. Antennae short and stout, with
   articles 9-10 as long as wide, and the last article twice as long as
   wide.
C1 Degiovanni, Augusto; Via A Costa 6, Bubano Di Mordano, BO, I-40027,
   Italy, Italy.
EM gusto.a@libero.it
SC Zoology

   Eurasia

   Anthicidae

TI New data on the Xantholinini of the Oriental Region 31. New species and
   new records from Laos of the Zoological Museum of Copenhagen (Insecta
   Coleoptera Staphylinidae).
AU Bordoni, Arnaldo (arnaldo.bordoni@libero.it) 
SO Quaderno di Studi e Notizie di Storia Naturale della Romagna
VL 36
PS 105-113
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Pachycorynus phou sp. n., Achmonia solodovnikovi sp. n., Metosina
   laotiana sp. n., Indomorphus laotianus sp. n. are described from Laos;
   Pachycorynus Thai Bordoni, 2002 is new to Laos; new records are listed
   for other two species. Notes are provided on the genus Achmonia Bordoni,
   2004 and the following synonymies are proposed: Achmonia Bordoni, 2004 =
   Daolus Bordoni, 2004, syn. n., Daolus being a junior synonym of
   Achmonia; Thyreocephalus sondaicus Bernhauer, 1915 = Achmonia doloc
   Bordoni, 2004, syn. n.: the taxon takes the name Achmonia sondaica
   (Bernhauer, 1915) and is the type species of the genus. The following
   species are transferred from genus Thyreocephalus to genus Achmonia: A.
   gestroi (Fauvel, 1895) comb. n. (Burma, Thailand), A. nigra (Bordoni,
   2009a) comb. n. (China: Zhejiang), A. shibatai (Bordoni, 2010) comb. n.
   (Taiwan), A. wogwog (Bordoni, 2005) comb. n. (Australia), A. cyanoptera
   (Erichson, 1839) comb. n. (Australia).

   Florence, I-50125, Italy, Italy.

AN ZOOR14910043110
DT Article
TI Complementary herpetological Observations on the Saiq Plateau and in the
   Jebel al-Akhdar, Sultanate of Oman.
FT Erganzende herpetologische Beobachtungen auf dem Saiq-Plateau und im
   Jebel al-Akhdar, Sultanat Oman.
AU Grossmann, Wolfgang (wg-gekko@t-online.de) 
   Kowalski, Thomas
   Zwanzig, Bernd Michael
   Zilger, Hans-Juergen
SO Sauria
VL 34
IS 4
PS 3-18
PD Dezember 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Complementary herpetological Observations on the Saiq Plateau and in the
   Jebel al-Akhdar, Sultanate of Oman Amphibia: Anura: Bufonidae:
   Duttaphrynus arabicus: not previously recognised, but readily
   distinguished from D. dhufarensis by its advertisement call (coll. At
   ephemeral, partly dammed-up water body in Wadi Bani Habib, 13 July, from
   21:45 h) and morphology on close inspection; fresh metamorphs in Aug.,
   numerous near water bodies, but also in dried-up pools; further records
   from water holes in wadis at Al Ayn, and in wadis Saiq and Qtm.
   Duttaphrynus dhufarensis: found and photographed already in Wadi Muadin
   (about 635 m a.s.l.) on 11 Apr.2009 around 01:25 h, and Wadi Bani Habib
   (about 1850 m) on 06 Oct.2010, 12:35 h, but not originally identified as
   such; populations appear to be very sparse; syntopic with D. arabicus;
   1st record from the Saiq Plateau. Reptilia: Sauna: Agamidae:
   Pseudotrapelus sinaitus sinaitus: 22 male and 4 female specs. on Saiq
   Plateau in July; females in various colour patterns and with bright blue
   to brown heads, but always displaying pairs of orange red dorsolateral
   spots; males and females close together (< 5 m) on 3 occasions; no
   juveniles (probably hatching only later in the year); obviously more
   prominent in July than in spring and autumn; highly gravid females in
   Aug.; 1 subadult at Diana's Point on 21 Febr., 15:00 h. Gekkonidae:
   Asaccus montanus: several adults of both sexes and some subadults, but
   no juvs., around parking lot in Wadi Bani Habib in July & Aug.; highly
   gravid females in Aug.; 1 juv., 6 subadults, 7 females and 2 males on 21
   Febr. betw. 20:55 and 22:00 h; weather rather cool (12.5[degree]C on the
   thermometer of the Jabel al-Akhdar Hotel at 22:40 h); all in spots
   protected from wind on walls and rock faces that palpably emitted stored
   heat; relatively low number of males noted once more. Bunopus spatalurus
   hajarensis: another juv. right next to lavatory at parking lot in Wadi
   Bani Habib (20:55 h) in July; 1 ad. male, 1 female & 1 juv. in Aug. not
   far from previous two records and again at a road; distribution on Saiq
   Plateau needs further study, but finds of altogether three juvs. suggest
   reproducing population with hatching in period July thru October.
   Hemidactylus luqueorum: adults in and in front of fairly large cave in
   Wadi Saiq above town; 1 adult male with 2 juvs, at entrance on 13 July
   (about 17:00 h), fleeing into cave on approach; in February, cave
   contained 16 geckos clustered in groups of 5-7, with one group of 2
   males, 3 females & 2 subadults being "huddled up"; cave cool in July,
   but very warm and humid in Febr. (outside temperatures: 22 Febr., 22:40
   h: 10[degree]C; 23 Febr., 18:00 h: 11[degree]C, 19:50 h: 9,5[degree]C;
   24 Febr., 05:10 h: 6,5[degree]C); one find of spec. some 2.50 m above
   ground on 7-8 cm acacia tree in Wadi Muaydin on 10 July; a large pair
   with regenerated tails and one single spec. with original tail on
   outside wall of house in Wadi Qtm in Aug.; the pair would retreat
   through gaps inside the dwelling on approach. Pristurus celerrimus, P.
   gasperetti gallagheri, P. rupestris rupestris: in July & Aug.; P.
   celerrimus and rupestris active at 04:50 h, numerous; P. gasperetti
   gallagheri only on stems of bushes (Diana's Point), trees (e.g., on
   pomegranate trees, Wadi Saiq), deadwood in fences (Wadi Saiq), and on
   stone steps in Wadi Bani Habib, comparatively uncommon in Febr., July &
   Aug.; P. celerrimus and rupestris often seen basking in Febr.; all P.
   celerrimus seen were very dark in colour and greatly lacking contrast;
   only 1 spec. of P. gasperetti gallagheri found on Saiq Plateau (on rocks
   at Al Manakhir Dam, 21 Febr., around 17:15 h) after one had already been
   spotted in Wadi Muaydin (same day, around 01:35 h). Lacertidae:
   Omanosaura jayakari: scarce in July (4 juvs, from previous year, 4
   adults within 6 d); more common in Aug. (5 ad., 7 subad., 4 juv.); 1
   spec. found basking in Wadi Saiq, near rock crevice that was used as a
   retreat, on 22 Febr., 12:10 h. O. cyanura: not recorded in July or
   Febr., but 1 juv. spec. on rock face in Wadi Qtm on 7. Aug. around 15.00
   h; drinking from water puddle; unsuccessful captive propagation is
   presumably related to constant stress from keeping pairs that affects
   development of eggs; hatchlings then behave abnormally and are
   short-lived; sexes should be kept separated and united only for mating.
   Scincidae: Ablepharus pannonicus: adults scarce in July, but hatchlings
   common in gardens of Wadi Saiq (2 adults, >20 juvs.) betw. 15.00 and
   15:50 h; 1 juv. observed stealing load from an ant, consuming it, but
   not bothering the ant itself; no sighting in gardens of Al Ayn in Febr.,
   but 6 adults and 2 juvs. seen in gardens of Saiq Town on 22. Febr. betw.
   12:20 and 13:30 h; 70 (45 juv.) specs. counted in stretch of 230 x <1.20
   m (about 276 m2) in the Gardens of Saiq (Sayq) within 20 mins. in Aug.
   Trachylepis tessellata: 1 female spec. on summit of mountain surrounded
   by meandering Wadi Bani Habib (23[degree]04'15''N, 57[degree]36'11''E;
   1856 m; July); not particularly shy; discharged 1 egg shortly after
   capture; no sightings in February; previous finds (KOWALSKI et al.2011)
   were from 1950 m a.s.l. (Wadi Qtm) and 2003 m (near Al-Ayn); highly
   gravid female on loose-rock demarcation wall in the old decaying village
   in Wadi Bani Habib on 7 Aug. 16:45 h; finds of 3rd and 4th specs.
   suggest reproducing population. Serpentes: Colubridae: Platyceps
   rhodorachis: 1 patternless, light beige grey spec. next to walkway betw.
   a fallaj and a fence in gardens of Saiq Town in Wadi Saiq on 15 July,
   16:00 h. Telescopus dhara: 1 spec. on Saiq Plateau DOR at
   23[degree]04'30,40''N; 57[degree]38'58,56''E; 1979 m, on 9 Aug. at 21:05
   h; 1st record from Saiq Plateau; male with SVL 706, TL 128 mm (tL 834
   mm), dorsals smooth, in 21 rows at midbody, 3 + 260 ventrals, anal scute
   entire, 70 + 1 subcaudals, divided, rostral wider than high; nasals
   singular, with suture behind nostril, internasals wider than long;
   prefrontal shorter than frontal, frontal longer than its distance from
   tip of snout, parietal longer than frontal and longer than wide, 1/1
   loreals, nearly twice as long as wide, 1/1 preoculars, 2/2 postoculars,
   9/9 supralabials, 3,4,5/3,4,5 touching orbit, 11/11 infralabials,
   anterior chin shields longer than posterior ones. Viperidae:
   Pseudocerastes persicus: DOR to Wadi Bani Habib (23[degree]04'23''N,
   57[degree]37'46''E; 1946 m) on 13 July, 21:20 h; 1st from Saiq Plateau;
   presence known to locals in Wadis Saiq and Bani Habib who distinguish
   betw. harmless diurnal and potentially dangerous nocturnal snakes.
   Reptiles of Jebel Akhdar region not found as yet on the Saiq Plateau
   >1800 m: Asaccus gallagheri: record of gravid female on boulder at
   parking bay at road onto Saiq Plateau at 1685 m (23[degree]00'9''N,
   57[degree]41'56''E), 10 July, 04:40 h. Asaccus platyrhynchus: juv. on
   boulder at same parking bay at 1685 m, 10 July, 04:40 h, adult female at
   same locality on 14 July, 20:40 h; further specs. on far side of newly
   erected concrete barrier wall, in company of several Hemidactylus
   luqueorum; road construction could facilitate vertical dispersal by
   providing perfect shelters in joints betw. concrete block segments, by
   storing and releasing heat on the lee side, and road illumination
   attracting arthropod food. Hemidactylus hajarensis: several specs. in
   tributary wadi of Wadi Muaydin (22[degree]57'17.13''N,
   57[degree]39'40.05''E; 637 m) in July 2011, Febr. 2012, Aug. 2012;
   ground-dwelling, on pebbles in wadi bed and boulders at edge; sympatric
   with H. luqueorum. Echis omanensis: presence on Saiq Plateau likely;
   another record from a tributary wadi of Wadi Muaydin, where spec. was
   perched on edge of rock crevice in steep cliff some 220 cm above ground,
   ambushing geckos, in July 2011, and yet another from same site on 7 Aug.
   2012 around 00:35 h, active on the ground.
C1 Grossmann, Wolfgang; Wulfila Ufer 33, Berlin, D-12105, Germany, Germany.
EM wg-gekko@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 0176-9391
BD Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia
DE Amphibia; Reptilia [Checklists / Updated checklist / New record] [Oman /
   Jebel al-Akhdar & Saiq Plateau / Biology; distribution]. 
   Duttaphrynus dhufarensis; Pseudocerastes persicus; Telescopus dhara
   [Oman / Saiq Plateau / Biology; new record]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Bufonidae, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata, Serpentes, Colubridae,
   Viperidae
OR Amphibia (Vertebrata): [New record]. 
   Reptilia (Vertebrata): [New record]. 
   Duttaphrynus dhufarensis (Bufonidae): [New record]. 
   Telescopus dhara (Colubridae): [New record]. 
   Pseudocerastes persicus (Viperidae): [New record].

AN ZOOR14910043111
DT Article
TI Observations on Phelsuma modesta MERTENS, 1970, with Annotations on the
   Taxonomic Status of its Subspecies and new Locality Records from the
   South of Madagascar.
FT Beobachtungen an Phelsuma modesta MERTENS, 1970, mit Anmerkungen uber
   den taxonomischen Status ihrer Unterarten sowie neuen Fundortnachweisen
   im Suden Madagaskars.
AU Hofmann, Thomas (chelydra2@freenet.de) 
   Trautmann, Gerd
SO Sauria
VL 34
IS 4
PS 19-38
PD Dezember 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Observations on Phelsuma modesta MERTENS, 1970, with Annotations on the
   Taxonomic Status of its Subspecies and new Locality Records from the
   South of Madagascar New locality records and ecological and phenotypic
   observations: Isaka-Ivondro and Ambahibe (24[degree]46'S,
   46[degree]51'E): area used for rice, fruit and livestock farming; very
   large population, most common in orchards; Andohahela appears to be
   northern limit of distribution, as no specs. were found in adjacent
   rainforest; Ambahibe surrounded by mountains in N (Andohahela), W and E
   that prevent geckos from dispersing further; found only in foothills
   irrespective of suitable habitats on Wand E mountain slopes; of the
   "Isaka" chromotype (blue head mask, blue tail); 31 specs. examined (17
   males, 13 females, 1 juvenile); only one very old male (SVL 43, TL 49 mm
   (40 mm reg.)) lacked blue colouration; largest male 45 + 54 mm; largest
   female 89 mm tL. Evonse: south betw. Isaka-Ivondro and Ifarantsa;
   "Isaka" chromotype syntopic with specs. lacking all blue; all specs. S
   of Ifarantsa without blue head mask and tail; not any specs. of the
   "trautmanni" chromotype (type locality); 1 entirely grey male found at
   Taolanaro (Fort Dauphin), lacked the 3 dark grey anterodorsal streaks
   typical of trautmanni; specs. from farther S with green head mask and
   tail. Tsimelahy, Andohahela (Plot 2) (24[degree]57'S 46[degree]37'E):
   small population living on elephant's ear plants at lower waterfall near
   camping site in river valley ca. 58 km W of Fort-Dauphin; possibly of
   anthropogenic origin; males with bluish greyish green ground colour and
   pale green head mask; females with standard grey colour pattern like
   stall other localities; HARTIG (pers. comm.) found blue-masked (almost
   "Isaka" type) specs. in Tsimelahy. Tsihombe (25[degree]19'S
   45[degree]29'E): ca. 62 km W of Ambovombe; probably westernmost locality
   of P. m. modesta; in and outside of village on agavas; quite homogeneous
   "Tsihombe" chromotype; males green with green head mask, turquoise-blue
   tail and distinct black lateral stripe. Ankarangotaky (Anjampaly),
   Sabali region (25[degree]27'S 45[degree]36'E): males on three coconut
   palm trees; "Tsihombe" and "Isaka" chromotypes. Talaky be
   (25[degree]26'S 45[degree]43'E): males on agava and prickly pear plants
   & on fences; "Tsihombe" and "Isaka" types plus uniform green specs., all
   with distinct black lateral stripe; syntopic with P. breviceps (HOFMANN
   & MOGENBURG unpubl.). Antaritariky (25[degree]22'S 45[degree]42'E): ca.
   10 km NE Talaky be; large population on agavas; males highly variable,
   entirely green, green with blue mask, green with bluish turquoise tail,
   green with blue mask and blue tail; all with distinct lateral stripe.
   Ikonda (Ikonda Beach) (25[degree]15'S 46[degree]53'E): all chromotypes;
   1 male with particularly intense colours and blue head mask that
   extended to the anterior back and blue tail. Ambandrika (Sainte-Luce)
   (24[degree]46'S 47[degree]10'E): clearly distinct from all known modesta
   forms, therefore referred to as P. cf. modesta; males light blue on
   head, back and tail, with red specks or vermiculations; red vertebral
   stripe with flanking red speckles may be present; subadult males with
   blue spotting on grey background; no green colours in this population
   (!); females differ from typical P. modesta in that they have a striped,
   reticulated or marbled dark pattern on a grey to light greyish beige
   background that may be replaced with light blue dots on dorsum and tail
   when excited; uniform grey when stressed; juveniles grey with fairly
   large white spots; no lateral stripe; largest male (n=7) 35 + 39 mm (13
   reg. ); no morphological differences to typical modesta; preliminary
   genetic results inconclusive (GEHRING pers. comm), suggest closest
   relationship to P. modesta from Manantantely (green ground colour, green
   mask, green tail, and lateral stripe present!). Distribution of P. m.
   leiogaster: records from S of Tulear in Anantsona (Saint-Augustin)
   (23[degree]34'S 43[degree]46) on Onilahy River; on trees and buildings;
   syntopic with large population of P. mutabilis; and slightly more N, at
   the Hotel Mangrove; and at Sakaraha village (22[degree]54'S
   44[degree]31'E), some 100 km NE Tulear (HARTIG pers. comm.). Taxonomic
   results: P. modesta are highly variable in their colour pattern within
   and between populations; distinguishing between P. m. modesta and isakae
   on the basis of differences in morphology, size, colour schemes and
   genetics (ROCHA et al. 2009, 2010) not tenable; P. m. isakae syn. nov.
   of P. m. modesta; P. m. leiogaster remains valid, as is suggested by DNA
   (ROCHA et al. 2010); apparently tending more to red striped pattern vs.
   spotted/dotted pattern in modesta; geographically separated (S & SE vs.
   SW Madagascar); morphological differences indistinct, with a statistic
   tendency towards more preanofemoral pores in modesta (20-23 (av. 22;
   n=20) vs. 20-21 (av. 20; n=17)); modesta holotype with 16 (and subadult
   paratype with 8) preanofemoral pores not taken into consideration. Notes
   on types of P. m. modesta: unique in having no lateral stripes; fading
   in preservative unlikely as suggested by other material examined;
   holotype with unique gular scales; 16 preanofemoral pores are way below
   range of all other (preserved & live) samples; no specs. in older
   literature that could be addressed as P. modesta today in spite of large
   collections and commonness of sp. in S Madagascar save some P. dubia
   from Ambovombe and St. Augustine (extralimital for P. dubia) mentioned
   by ANGEL (1942) that cannot be found in the MHNP anymore. General
   conclusions: P. modesta appears to be highly adaptable and continually
   extends its range by anthropogenic displacement, which explains its
   homogeneity in remote locations and its heterogeneity in more readily
   accessible places (e.g., Ft. Dauphin, Ambovombe).
C1 Hofmann, Thomas; Sachsenstr 47, Zittau, D-02763, Germany, Germany.
EM chelydra2@freenet.de
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0176-9391
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Colour and luminescence;
   Integument; Integumentary derivatives; Evolution; Variation; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Phelsuma modesta [Colour /  / new record; systematics] [Scales /
   Pholidosis / ] [Morphological variation /  / ] [Madagascar / South /
   distribution]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI Brachysaura minor (HARDWICKE & GRAY, 1827) (Sauria: Agamidae: Agaminae)
   from Madhya Pradesh, India, with Notes on its Morphology, Distribution
   and Natural History.
FT Brachysaura minor (HARDWICKE & GRAY, 1827) (Sauria: Agamidae: Agaminae)
   in Madhya Pradesh, Indien, mit Anmerkungen zu Morphologie, Verbreitung
   und Lebensweise.
AU Ingle, Mukesh (mukeshingle@gmail.com) 
   Sarsavan, Anil
   Pawar, Manohar
SO Sauria
VL 34
IS 4
PS 47-55
PD Dezember 2012
PY 2012
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Brachysaura minor (HARDWICKE & GRAY, 1827) (Sauria: Agamidae: Agaminae)
   from Madhya Pradesh, India, with Notes on its Morphology, Distribution
   and Natural History New locality: hill surrounded by soy bean fields
   with small pockets of dry deciduous thorn forest at the village of
   Biklakhedi, 9 km S Shajapur, Shajapur District
   (22[degree]22'-38[degree]85'N, 76[degree]17'-44[degree]98'E, 508 m
   a.s.l.), Madhya Pradesh, India; 21 Sept. 2010, betw. 10.00-18.00 h.
   Observations: all over the hilltop, with sightings on boulders (11
   instances), in and around bushes (8), on the ground (10), below rocks
   (6), and in cultivated fields (3); all sightings during the day and in
   the evening hours, none at night; sympatric herpetofauna: Calotes
   versicolor, Hemidactylus brookii, Hemidactylus triedrus, Eutropis
   carinata, Eutropis macularia, Varanus bengalensis, Xenochrophis
   piscator; generally inoffensive by nature, but powerful jaws can inflict
   a painful bite; can run at speed; active mainly late in the day, but can
   also be seen during the day in the rainy winter season; sightings
   frequent during monsoon period (July-October), less frequent during the
   post-monsoon period (November-February), and no sightings at all in
   summer (March-May); feeds on ants and lives where ants are common;
   waiting for ants to appear on the surface, the agamas would then snatch
   them up with the help of the tongue flicking from the open mouth; also
   feeding upon the Indian red scorpion (Hottentotta tumulus), a centipede
   (Scolopendra sp.) that is common in the area, and different arthropods,
   beetles, termites, spiders, caterpillars, grubs, grasshoppers,
   butterflies etc.; some direct threats from anthropogenic activities such
   as ploughing etc. during the monsoon season when it appears in numbers
   to feed and mate while sowing of crops takes place; otherwise not
   directly persecuted, but rather worshipped by locals and called Khet
   Rakhwali ("Field Guard").
C1 Ingle, Mukesh; Snake Res Org, C Sect, Ujjain, Madhya Pradesh, 456010,
   India, India.
EM mukeshingle@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Anatomy &Morphology; Nutrition
   &Dietetics; Entomology
SN 0176-9391

   Predators; Life habit; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Arthropoda; Formicidae; Hottentotta tumulus [Reptilian predators /
   Brachysaura minor / Predator prey record] [Madhya Pradesh /  / ]. 
   Brachysaura minor [Biometrics / Morphometrics / arthropod prey; predator
   prey record; new record] [General morphology /  / ] [Prey / Arthropoda /

   (Hymenoptera) / ] [Feeding behaviour /  / ] [Terrestrial habit / Hilltop

DT Article
TI Choeradoplana crassiphalla sp nov (Platyhelminthes: Tricladida:
   Geoplanidae): a new species of land planarian from the Atlantic Forest
   of Argentina.
AU Negrete, Lisandro
   Brusa, Francisco (fbrusa@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
SO Studies on Neotropical Fauna and Environment
VL 47
IS 3
PS 227-237
PD Dec 1 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB A new species of land planarian from northeastern Argentina,
   Choeradoplana crassiphalla sp. nov., is described. This is the first
   report of Choeradoplana in the Atlantic Forest of Argentina and the
   second species of the genus for this country. Choeradoplana includes
   nine species of Neotropical land planarians. The new species is light
   brown with a thin clearer median stripe. The pharynx is bell-shaped. The
   copulatory apparatus presents a short and very high and thick penis
   papilla. Choeradoplana crassiphalla is compared with other species of
   the genus, especially with Ch. marthae, due to the similarity of the
   copulatory apparatus.
C1 Brusa, Francisco; Univ Nacl La Plata, Fac Ciencias Nat & Museo, La
   Plata, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Argentina.
EM fbrusa@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
RI Brusa, Francisco/N-1250-2019
OI Brusa, Francisco/0000-0003-2206-1560; Negrete,
   Lisandro/0000-0003-3398-6606
SC Zoology
SN 0165-0521
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Choeradoplana [Argentina / Atlantic Forest / New record]. 
   Choeradoplana crassiphalla [Argentina /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Platyhelminths
ST Animalia, Platyhelminthes, Turbellaria
OR Choeradoplana (Turbellaria): [New record].

TI New Species and Records of Psocoptera from the Ragged Islands Group,
   Bahamas.
AU Mockford, Edward L. (elmockf@ilstu.edu) 
SO Transactions of the American Entomological Society (Philadelphia)
VL 138
PS 1-19
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A small collection of Psocoptera based on a rapid survey of the Ragged
   Islands group of the Bahamas contains 14 species in eight families. Six
   species are new and are described in the following genera: Echmepteryx
   (one), Cerobasis (one), Blaste (one), Indiopsocus (three).
   Pseudocaecilius similis Turner, described from Jamaica, is a new junior
   synonym of Pseudocaecilius tahitiensis (Karny).

DT Article
TI Tettigoniidae (Orthoptera) from Turkey and the Middle East II.
AU Unal, Mustafa (unal@ibu.edu.tr) 
SO Transactions of the American Entomological Society (Philadelphia)
VL 138
PS 21-54
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB This is the second part of the taxonomic studies on Palaearctic
   Tettigoniidae carried out in some European and Turkish collections.
   Sixty species and subspecies collected from Turkey and the Middle East
   countries are given. The genera Farsodecticus Mirzayans and Zagrosiella
   Mirzayans are studied and discussed for the first time after their
   descriptions. Farsodecticus is included to the tribe Tettigoniini. Known
   species of Mixodusa Stolyarov are compared using both sexes. Anterastes
   uludaghensis species group is reviewed. Three species of Uvarovistia
   Maran are given with comparable new illustrations. The genus Koroglus
   Unal is validated with a discussion and comparison to the A.
   uludaghensis sp. group. Two new species, Lithodusa mirzayani sp.n. from
   Iran, Platycleis (s.str.) kibris sp.n. from Cyprus are described. A
   lectotype for Eupholidoptera smyrnensis (Brunner, 1882) is designated.
   Two species are synonymized: Anterastes ucari Ciplak, 2004 with A.
   babadaghi Uvarov, 1939 and Eupholidoptera femorata Ciplak, 1999 with E.
   unimacula Karabag, 1956. Besides, the priority of the paper of
   Schulthess-Rechberg (1882) and the book of Brunner von Wattenwyl (1882)
   is discussed and the precedence is given to Schulthess-Rechberg.
   Therefore, Brunner's taxa Anterastes serbicus Brunner, 1882 and
   Metrioptera (Broughtonia) domogledi (Brunner, 1882) are synonymized with
   Anterastes serbicus (Schulthess-Rechberg, 1882) and Metrioptera
   (Broughtonia) domogleti (Schulthess-Rechberg, 1882) respectively and
   currently synonyms two more taxa described by Schulthess are discussed
   under the account of A. serbicus in the text. The authorship of the
   tribes Pholidopterini and Platycleidini is discussed. Keys to the
   species of Lithodusa Bey-Bienko, 1951, Uvarovistia Maran, 1953 and A.
   uludaghensis sp. group are prepared. Besides, many taxonomic, systematic
   and faunistic discussions for the taxa are given. To support the
   descriptions and discussions 152 figures are provided.
C1 Unal, Mustafa; Abant Izzet Baysal Univ, Fen Edebiyat Fak, Bolu,
   TR-14280, Turkey, Turkey.
EM unal@ibu.edu.tr
SC Zoology
SN 0002-8320

   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia

   Pholidoptera femorata (Saltatoria): [New record]. 
   Pholidopterini - Ramme 1951 (Saltatoria): [Authorship, P. 38]. 
   Phytodrymadusa longipes (Saltatoria): [New record]. 
   Platycleidini - Brunner von Wattenwyl 1893 (Saltatoria): [Syn nov,
   Rhacocleidini Brunner von Wattenwyl 1893, p. 28; Authorship, P. 28]. 
   Platycleis (Platycleis) kibris (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Cyprus, P. 28]. 
   Scotodrymadusa annulipes (Saltatoria): [New record].

TI The Macroinvertebrate Fauna of the Mississippi River.
AU Harrison, Audrey B. (audreybharrison@gmail.com) 
   Morse, John C.
SO Transactions of the American Entomological Society (Philadelphia)
VL 138
PS 55-72
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB The invertebrate fauna of the Mississippi River is compiled from
   published material (215 total taxa) is compiled from published material
   (205 taxa) and records of 10 new taxa obtained in a dietary study of
   sturgeon in the Lower Mississippi River. The previously undocumented
   taxa are Leptophlebia sp. (Ephemeroptera: Leptophlebiidae), Pseudiron
   centralis McDunnough (Ephemeroptera: Pseudironidae), Gillotia sp.
   (Diptera: Chironomidae), Lipiniella sp. (Diptera: Chironomidae),
   Metriocnemus fuscipes (Meigen) (Diptera: Chironomidae), Parachironomus
   sp. (Diptera: Chironomidae), Paratendipes basidens Townes (Diptera:
   Chironomidae), Polypedilum flavum (Johannsen) (Diptera: Chironomidae),
   Saetheria sp. (Diptera: Chironomidae), and Zavrelia sp. (Diptera:
   Chironomidae).

DT Article
TI A taxonomic study on the genus Rhynchoticida Boucek (Hymenoptera:
   Chalcidoidea: Torymidae) of Vietnam.
AU Narendran, T.C. (drtcnaren-dran@yahoo.com) 
   van Achterberg, C.
SO Zoologische Mededelingen (Leiden)
VL 86
IS 2-8
PS 485-496
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species of the genus Rhynchoticida Boucek, 1978 (Torymidae:
   Toryminae) from Vietnam are revised and keyed. Four species are
   recognized of which two are new to science: Rhynchoticida vriesi spec.
   nov. and R. vietnamica spec. nov. In addition, R. mini Boucek, 1978, and
   R. frenalis Boucek, 1978, are reported from Vietnam. The genus and all
   known species of the genus Rhynchoticida (five species) are diagnosed
   and keyed.
C1 Narendran, T.C.; Univ Calicut, Dept Zool, Calicut, Kerala, 673635,
   India, India.
EM drtcnaren-dran@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 0024-0672

   region; Eurasia; Asia

   Rhynchoticida frenalis [Vietnam /  / New record; systematics]. 
   Rhynchoticida vietnamica; Rhynchoticida vriesi [Vietnam /  / New
   species].

   Chalcidoidea, Torymidae

PT J
AN ZOOR14910042548
DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Salyavata Amyot & Audinet-Serville, 1843
   (Heteroptera: Reduviidae: Salyavatinae).
AU van Doesburg, P.H. (phvdoes@hetnet.nl) 
   Forero, D.
SO Zoologische Mededelingen (Leiden)
VL 86
IS 2-8
PS 515-568
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Neotropical genus Salyavata Amyot & Audinet-Serville, 1843
   (Heteroptera: Reduviidae) is revised. Eleven species are recognized as
   valid, with six described as new, arranged in three species groups. The
   variegata-group comprises: S. variegata Amyot & Audinet-Serville, 1843;
   S. dominica spec. nov. from Dominica and Lesser Antilles; S. macmahanae
   van Doesburg & Brailovsky, 2001; S. englemani spec. nov. from Panama,
   Colombia and Venezuela; and S. webbi spec. nov. from the Amazon region
   in Brazil. The nigrofasciata-group comprises: S. nigrofasciata Costa
   Lima, 1935; S. wygodzinskyi Maldonado, 1955; S. alvarengai spec. nov.
   from Brazil; and S. brasiliensis spec. nov. from Brazil. The
   cornuta-group is proposed for S. cornuta Wygodzinsky, 1943 and S.
   berengeri spec. nov. from French Guiana, Trinidad and Venezuela. The
   first known female specimen of S. nigrofasciata Costa Lima is described
   and figured. Eggs and nymphs are documented for some species. Further, a
   summary of the species, a key to the species groups and to all species,
   and distribution maps are provided.
C1 van Doesburg, P.H.; Nat Biodivers Ctr, Postbus 9517, Leiden, NL-2300 RA,
   Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM phvdoes@hetnet.nl
SC Zoology
SN 0024-0672
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies; South America
DE Salyavata [Neotropical region /  / Biology; distribution; systematics]. 
   Salyavata alvarengai; Salyavata brasiliensis; Salyavata webbi [Brazil / 
   / New species]. 
   Salyavata berengeri [Trinidad and Tobago /  / New species] [French
   Guiana /  / ] [Guyana /  / ] [Venezuela /  / ]. 
   Salyavata dominica [Dominica /  / New species]. 
   Salyavata englemani [Costa Rica /  / New species] [Panama /  / ]
   [Colombia /  / ] [Ecuador /  / ] [Venezuela /  / ]. 
   Salyavata macmahanae [Panama /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Cimicomorpha,
   Reduvoidea, Reduviidae
OR Salyavata - Amyot & Audinet-Serville 1843 (Reduviidae): [Revision, P.
   516; Key to species groups, P. 520]. 
   Salyavata alvarengai (Reduviidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 542]. 
   Salyavata berengeri (Reduviidae): [Sp nov, French Guiana, P. 554]. 
   Salyavata brasiliensis (Reduviidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 546]. 
   Salyavata cornuta - Wygodzinsky 1943 (Reduviidae): [Redescription, P.
   551]. 
   Salyavata cornuta species group (Reduviidae): [Key to species, P. 551]. 
   Salyavata dominica (Reduviidae): [Sp nov, Dominica, P. 528]. 
   Salyavata englemani (Reduviidae): [Sp nov, Panama, P. 524].

   521]. 
   Salyavata webbi (Reduviidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 538].

TI The genus Dolichomitus Smith, 1877 (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae:
   Pimplinae) in the Ukrainian Carpathians, with description of a new
   species.
AU Varga, O. (Sancho.Varga@gmail.com) 
SO Zoologische Mededelingen (Leiden)
VL 86
IS 2-8
PS 569-578
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Fifteen species of Dolichomitus are recorded from the Ukrainian
   Carpathians. All the recorded species are new for the studied region and
   four species, D. aciculatus (Hellen), D. excavatus Zwakhals, D. messor
   (Gravenhorst) and D. terebrans (Ratzeburg), are new for Ukraine. One new
   species, Dolichomitus sirenkoi spec. nov., is described and illustrated.
   A key to the imperator-species group of Dolichomitus is given.
C1 Varga, O.; Vasyl Stefanyk Precarpathian Natl Univ, Dept Biol & Ecol,
   Galytska St 201, Ivano Frankivsk, Ukraine, Ukraine.

   Dolichomitus terebrans [Ukraine /  / New record]. 
   Dolichomitus sirenkoi [Ukraine /  / New species].

DT Article
TI Review of the Philippine taxa formerly assigned to the genus Amphicnemis
   Selys. Part I: Overview and descriptions of three new genera (Odonata:
   Coenagrionidae).
AU Villanueva, R.J.T. (rjtvillanueva@gmail.com) 
SO Zoologische Mededelingen (Leiden)
VL 86
IS 2-8
PS 579-603
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Philippine species formerly assigned to the genus Amphicnemis Selys
   are reviewed. Three new genera Luzonobasis gen. nov., Pandanobasis gen.
   nov. and Sangabasis gen. nov. are erected. Amphicnemis isabela is
   synonymised with Amphicnemis glauca and transferred to Luzonobasis gen.
   nov. Amphicnemis cantuga and A. mcgregori are transferred to
   Pandanobasis gen. nov. Amphicnemis braulitae, A. circularis, A. dentifer
   and A. furcata are transferred to Sangabasis gen. nov. The rest of the
   Philippine Amphicnemis species are transferred to the genus Pericnemis
   Hagen. Two new species are described: Pandanobasis curacha spec. nov.
   and P. daku spec. nov.
C1 Villanueva, R.J.T.; Nat Biodivers Ctr, POB 9517, Leiden, NL-2300 RA,
   Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM rjtvillanueva@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0024-0672
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia

   Teinobasini [Land zones / Old World / Key to genera].

   Amphicnemis braulitae Villanueva 2005, p. 594]. 
   Sangabasis braulitae - (Villanueva 2005) (Odonata): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Amphicnemis, p. 595]. 
   Sangabasis circularis - (Lieftinck 1974) (Odonata): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Amphicnemis, p. 595].

PT J
AN ZOOR14909036694
DT Article
TI Xancithrix gen.n. (Copepoda: Calanoida), a new benthopelagic genus of
   Clausocalanoidea from deep Atlantic waters.
AU Markhaseva, Elena L. (markhaseva@yahoo.com) 
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 21
IS 4
PS 295-306
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new benthopelagic genus and species Xancithrix ohmani
   (Clausocalanoidea) with sensory setae on maxilla and maxilliped is
   described from females and males from the abyss of the South Atlantic. A
   new genus is proposed as it is amongst the most primitive bradfordian
   genera retaining the ancestral bradfordian setal pattern of mouth parts:
   the maxilliped praecoxal endites of the syncoxa have a setal sequence of
   1, 2, 3; the maxilla praecoxal endite and endopod with 5 and 9 setae
   respectively, and the maxillule praecoxal arthrite, coxal endite,
   proximal and distal basal endites, endopod, exopod and coxal epipodite
   has a setal sequence of 14, 5, 4, 5, 11, 10, and 9, respectively. This
   new genus is attributed to the Diaixidae and is distinct from all other
   diaixids in not having a rostrum, the maxilliped coxal endite with a
   small distal attenuation, and the P1 endopod lateral lobe bears a pore.
C1 Markhaseva, Elena L.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Nab 1, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM markhaseva@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 0136-006X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Xancithrix ohmani [South Atlantic /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Calanoida
OR Xancithrix (Calanoida): [Gen nov, Of family Diaixidae, Type species
   Xancithrix ohmani, p. 296]. 
   Xancithrix ohmani (Calanoida): [Sp nov, South Atlantic, P. 305]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14909036694
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14909036695
DT Article
TI Scorpions from Ennedi, Kapka and Tibesti, the mountains of Chad, with
   descriptions of nine new species (Scorpiones: Buthidae, Scorpionidae).
AU Lourenco, Wilson R. (arachne@mnhn.fr) 
   Duhem, Bernard
   Cloudsley-Thompson, John L.
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 21
IS 4
PS 307-338
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB Treating a collection of scorpions from the Ennedi, Kapka and Tibesti
   mountain massifs in Chad reveals an interesting fauna with several
   elements possibly endemic to these areas. Nine new species are
   described: Androctonus pallidus sp.n., Buthacus golovatchi sp.n.,
   Butheoloides (s.str.) granulatus sp.n., Buthus hassanini sp.n.,
   Compsobuthus boucheti sp.n., Hottentotta mateui sp.n., Orthochirus minor
   sp.n., Orthochirus tibesti sp.n. (Buthidae) and Scorpio ennedi sp.n.
   (Scorpionidae). Biogeographic comments are also added on the scorpion
   faunas of other Saharan massifs.

TI A synopsis of the genus Zyuzicosa Logunov, 2010 (Aranei: Lycosidae).
AU Logunov, D.V. (dpavuk@ngs.ru) 
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 21
IS 4
PS 349-362
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The paper presents a synopsis of and identification key to 10 species of
   the genus Zyuzicosa Logunov, 2010. Two species are described as new:
   Zyuzicosa kopetdaghensis sp.n. ([female]; Turkmenistan, SW Kopetdagh
   Mts) and Z. nessovi sp.n. ([male][female]; Kyrghyzstan, Dzhalal-Abad
   Region). The previously unknown males are described for two species: Z.
   laetabunda (Spassky, 1941) and Z. nenjukovi (Spassky, 1952). Two new
   combinations are proposed: Zyuzicosa nenjukovi (Spassky, 1952), comb.n.,
   ex. Tarentula; and Trochosa altera (Roewer, 1955) comb.n., ex Geolycosa.
   The distribution of Zyuzicosa is clarified on the basis of newly studied
   material. New locality records are provided for Z. fulviventris, Z.
   laetabunda, Z. nenjukovi and Z. turlanica.

TI Two new Stemonyphantes Menge, 1866 from Kazakhstan (Aranei: Linyphiidae:
   Stemonyphantinae).
AU Tanasevitch, Andrei V. (tanasevitch@gmail.com) 
   Esyunin, Sergei L.
   Stepina, Anna S.
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 21
IS 4
PS 363-368
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the linyphiid spider genus Stemonyphantes Menge, 1866
   are described: S. karatau sp.n. from the West Tien-Shang Mts,
   Kazakhstan, and S. taiganoides sp.n. from eastern Kazakhstan and the
   southern part of western Siberia. S. karatau sp.n. is similar to S.
   curvipes Tanasevitch, 1989, known from the northern Tien-Shang Mts; S.
   taiganoides sp.n. is close to the southern Siberian S. taiganus
   (Ermolajev, 1930). The latter species is recorded for the first time
   since its description, with detailed figures of the genitalia of both
   sexes provided.

TI A new species of Porrhomma Simon, 1884 from the mountains of southern
   Siberia, Russia (Aranei: Linyphiidae: Linyphiinae).
AU Tanasevitch, Andrei V. (tanasevitch@gmail.com) 
SO Arthropoda Selecta
VL 21
IS 4
PS 369-374
PD December 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Porrhomma magnum sp.n. is described from the mountains of southern
   Siberia, Russia. The new species resembles P. longjiangensis Zhu et
   Wang, 1983 (sp. revalid.), but differs by certain details of genital
   structure, in the significantly larger size, pale body coloration,
   strongly reduced eyes, as well as by the chaetotaxy pattern. P.
   longjiangense is resurrected from the synonymy with P. rakanum Yaginuma
   et Saito, 1981, being also rediagnosed and accompanied by figures of the
   genitalia of both sexes.

   Profsoyuznaya Str 84-32, Moscow, 117997, Russia, Russia.

AB A list of 28 spider species collected from the Antalya Province of
   Turkey is provided. Three species are reported for the Turkish spider
   fauna for the first time: Evarcha nepos (O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1872)
   (Salticidae); Xysticus loeffleri Roewer, 1955 and Xysticus
   thessalicoides Wunderlich, 1995 (both Thomisidae). One species - Berinda
   cooki sp.n. ([male]) (Gnaphosidae) - is described as new.

TI Further biting midges (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) in Canadian Cretaceous
   amber.

SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 144
IS 6
PS 758-766

LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A collection of 55 Canadian amber Ceratopogonidae is described,
   including two new species, Protoculicoides ciliatus Borkent and
   Stilobezzia pikei Borkent. The male of Protoculicoides depressus Boesel
   is newly described and the two males previously identified as members of
   this species are designated holotype and paratype of P. ciliatus. A new
   key to the species of Protoculicoides Boesel is provided. A male
   genitalia of Peronehelea chrimikalydia Borkent is additionally described
   and a specimen that is possibly a gynandromorph, a female with an
   associated male genitalia or a new species of Peronehelea Borkent is
   described.

DT Article
TI Insect predators in northeast China and their impacts on Aphis glycines.
AU Liu, Jian
   Xu, Weijun
   Wang, Qiuyu
   Zhao, Kuijun (kjzhao@163.com) 
SO Canadian Entomologist
VL 144
IS 6
PS 779-789
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 46
AB Predators of Aphis glycines Matsumura (Hemiptera: Aphididae) were
   surveyed and their ability to suppress A. glycines population growth was
   determined in Harbin, northeast China (45.4[degree]N, 126.4[degree]E).
   Field surveys were conducted on 21 fixed sampling sites in 2004 and 17
   in 2005. Impacts of natural enemies of A. glycines were studied using
   exclosure experiments. Thirteen natural enemies were found, the most
   abundant of which was Propylaea japonica (Thunberg), Harmonia axyridis
   (Pallas) (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae), Chrysopa sinica Tjeder, Chrysopa
   phyllochroma Wesmael, Chrysopa formosa Brauer (Neuroptera: Chrysopidae),
   Hemerobius humuli Linnaeus (Neuroptera: Hemerobiidae), Orius Wolff sp.
   (Heteroptera: Anthocoridae), Nabis stenoferus Hsiao (Heteroptera:
   Reduviidae), Deraeocoris punctulatus (Fallen) (Heteroptera: Miridae),
   and Episyrphus balteata (De Geer) (Diptera: Syrphidae). Three exclosure
   treatment types were established, large-mesh cages, small-mesh cages,
   and no cages. In exclosures, A. glycines density in small-mesh cages
   peaked at numbers 3.75-fold higher than in large-mesh cages and
   17.44-fold higher than on plants with no cages in 2004. In 2005, these
   numbers were 4.59-fold and 60.98-fold. Temperature was not a factor in
   exclosures, but relative humidity had significant effects. These results
   indicated that existing predator communities could partially suppress
   soybean aphid population density in soybean fields in northeast China.
C1 Zhao, Kuijun; NE Agr Univ, Coll Agr, 59 Mucai St, Harbin, 150030, China,
   China.
EM kjzhao@163.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0008-347X
BD Animals and man; Control; Ecology; Population dynamics; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Aphis glycines [Biological control /  / predator prey list] [Population
   density /  / ] [Predators /  / ] [China / Harbin / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Aphidoidea
OR Aphis glycines (Aphidoidea): [Prey]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14909036798
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14909036574
DT Article
TI The first Sinomastodon (Gomphotheriidae, Proboscidea) skull from the
   Quaternary in China.
AU Wang, Yuan (xiaowangyuan@ivpp.ac.cn) 
   Jin, ChangZhu
   Deng, ChengLong
   Wei, GuangBiao
   Yan, YaLing
SO Chinese Science Bulletin
VL 57
IS 36
PS 4726-4734
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB The first Sinomastodon (Gomphotheriidae, Proboscidea) skull of the Early
   Pleistocene, collected from the Renzidong Cave deposits in Anhui
   Province, Eastern China, is described here as S. jiangnanensis sp. nov.
   As the only brevirostrine trilophodont gomphotheriid known from the Old
   World, Sinomastodon was mainly indigenous to China from the Early
   Pliocene to the Pleistocene. Compared with a few single Pleistocene
   teeth previously found in China, S. jiangnanensis sp. nov. is
   represented by a relatively complete skull, mandible and dentition,
   which is the first discovery of a Quaternary Sinomastodon skull from
   China. With a brevirostrine, elephant-like skull, no lower tusks, and
   simple bunodont and trilophodont intermediate molars, the new species is
   morphologically distinct from other gomphotheres and should belong to
   the genus Sinomastodon. The new species is more progressive than S.
   hanjiangensis and the Pliocene type species S. intermedius in its skull
   and mandible morphology, but is evidently more primitive than the
   Pleistocene S. yangziensis in its molar morphology. The faunal analysis
   suggests that the emergence of S. jiangnanensis sp. nov. in Jiangnan
   area and its southward migration may have been related to a cooling
   event at the beginning of the Quaternary in Eastern China.
C1 Wang, Yuan; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Vertebrate Paleontol &
   Paleoanthropol, Beijing, 100044, China, China.
EM xiaowangyuan@ivpp.ac.cn
RI Deng, Chenglong/B-8881-2009; Deng, Chenglong/B-8871-2009
OI Deng, Chenglong/0000-0003-1848-3170
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1001-6538
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Sinomastodon jiangnanensis [Anhui /  / new species] [Pleistocene /  / ].
   
   Sinomastodontinae [Pleistocene /  / New subfamily]. 
TN Chordates; Elephants; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Proboscidea, Gomphotheriidae
OR Sinomastodon - Tobien, Chen & Li 1986 (Gomphotheriidae): [Diagnostic
   characters of subordinate taxa, Skull & mandible, p. 4732; Emended
   diagnosis, P. 4728; Referred to, New subfamily Sinomastodontinae, p.
   4731; Fossil]. 
   Sinomastodon jiangnanensis (Gomphotheriidae): [Sp nov, Anhui,
   Pleistocene, P. 4728; Fossil]. 
   Sinomastodontinae (Gomphotheriidae): [Subfam nov, Of family
   Gomphotheriidae, Type genus not given, p. 4731, Pleistocene; Fossil].

DT Article
TI REVISION OF CHINESE YAMATENTOMON (PROTURA: ACERENTOMATA: ACERENTOMIDAE),
   WITH DESCRIPTION OF ONE NEW SPECIES, REDESCRIPTION OF YAMATENTOMON
   YAMATO, AND KEY TO WORLD SPECIES.
AU Bu, Yun
   Wu, Dong Hui (ybu@sibs.ac.cn) 
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 95
IS 4
PS 839-847
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Chinese Yamatentomon is revised and Yamatentomon guoi sp. nov. is
   described from northeastern China. The new species is characterized by
   the extremely long sensillum b on foretarsus, short and slender Al setae
   on tergites I-VII, presence of P3a on tergites IV-VII, 5 pairs of
   A-setae on tergite VII, and pore arrangement on tergites IV-VI. The new
   species is similar to Y kunnepchupi Imadate, 1964, but can be
   distinguished by the length of sensilla b and e on foretarsus, and
   chaetotaxy of tergites IV and V. DNA barcodes for the new species are
   provided to give a reference for identification in the future. In
   addition, Yamatentomon yamato (Imadate & Yosii, 1956) was redescribed
   based on the specimens from type locality. An updated key to the world
   species of the genus was also provided.
C1 Wu, Dong Hui; Chinese Acad Sci, NE Inst Geog & Agroecol, Changchun,
   130012, China, China.
EM ybu@sibs.ac.cn

SN 0015-4040

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS SINOE (LEPIDOPTERA: GELECHIIDAE: LITINI) FROM

LA English
U1 0

AB A new species of Gelechiidae, Sinoe capsana sp. nov., is reported from
   southern Florida, USA. All specimens were recently caught in pheromone
   traps near tomato fields during an early detection survey for the tomato

DT Article
TI DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES OF ARBORIDIA (HEMIPTERA: AUCHENORRHYNCHA:
   CICADELLIDAE: TYPHLOCYBINAE) FROM CHINA.
AU Guglielmino, Adalgisa (guglielm@unitus.it) 
   Xu, Zaifu
   Bueckle, Christoph
   Dong, Wei
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 95
IS 4
PS 877-881
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB A new species of leafhopper, Arboridia sinensis sp. nov., belonging to
   the subgenus Arboridia Zachvatkin, 1946 s. str. and closely related to
   Arboridia (Arboridia) gaurii Thapa, 1989, A. cerna Dworakowska, 1977,
   and A. soror Dworakowska, 1977, is described from Yunnan, China. It
   differs from A. gaurii in the body coloration and aedeagus shape, and
   from A. cerna and A. soror also in the shape of its pygofer process. In
   Yunnan, China the new species lives on Zanthoxylum bungeanum Maximowicz
   (Rutaceae).
C1 Guglielmino, Adalgisa; Univ Tuscia, Dept Agr Forests Nat & Energy, Via
   San Camillo de Lellis, Viterbo, I-01100, Italy, Italy.

AB Tambinia bambusana sp. nov. (Hemiptera: Fulgoromorpha: Tropiduchidae:
   Tambiniini), a new species feeding on Dendrocalamus latiflorus Munro
   (Poaceae: Bambusoideae), is described and illustrated from Guizhou and
   Guangxi, China. This represents the first record of the members of genus
   Tambinia Stal feeding on bamboo. A key to all 25 species of Tambinia is
   given.

DT Article
TI POPULATION FLUCTUATIONS OF FORMICIDAE (HYMENOPTERA) AND ARANEAE
   (ARACHNIDA) IN TWO TILLAGE SYSTEMS IN THE REGION OF GUAIRA-SP.
AU Haddad, Gianni Queiroz (gihaddad2001@yahoo.com.br) 
   Cividanes, Francisco Jorge
   Fernandes Martins, Ivan Carlos
   Batista Correa, Lilian Roberta
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 95
IS 4
PS 1012-1018
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 15
AB The objective of this study was to elucidate population fluctuations of
   spider and ant species in forest fragments and adjacent soybean and corn
   crops under no-tillage and conventional tillage systems, and their
   correlations with meteorological factors. From Nov 2004 to Apr 2007
   sampling of these arthropods at Guaira, Sao Paulo state was done
   biweekly during the cropping season and monthly during the periods
   between crops. To obtain samples at each experimental site, pitfall
   traps were distributed in 2 transects of 200 m of which 100 m was in the
   crop, and 100 m was in the forest fragment. Temperature and rainfall
   were found to have major impacts on fluctuations in population densities
   of ants of the genus, Pheidole, in soybean and corn crops both grown
   with conventional tillage and no tillage systems.
C1 Haddad, Gianni Queiroz; Univ Estadual Paulista, Dept Fitossanidade,
   Rodovia Paulo Donato Castellane S-N, Jaboticabal, SP, BR-14884900 BC,
   Brazil, Brazil.

AB Two new species, Hilara metinaktasi Ciftci, Hasbenli and Ozgul sp. nov.
   and Hilara barlasi Ciftci, Hasbenli and Ozgul sp. nov., of the Hilara
   maura-species group are described from Turkey. Both sexes of the new
   species are described, genitalia and forelegs are illustrated. The
   relationships between the new species and related species are compared,
   and the systematic positions of the new species within the complexes of
   the H. maura-group are discussed. An updated key to species of Hilara of
   Turkey is given.

TI REVISION OF THE PLANTHOPPER GENUS TAMBINIA (HEMIPTERA: FULGOROMORPHA:
   TROPIDUCHIDAE) FROM CHINA, WITH DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES.
AU Men, Qiulei
   Qin, Daozheng (qindaozh0426@yahoo.com.cn) 
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 95
IS 4
PS 1095-1110
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB All 6 species of the genus Tambinia Stal, 1859 in China are reviewed,
   including 1 new species, T sinuata sp. nov. from Yunnan Province.
   Morphological descriptions, illustrations, molecular characteristics of
   the mitochondrial COI gene and an identification key for Chinese
   Tambinia species are provided. Pairwise distances, calculated by the
   Kimura-2-parameter model among the Tambinia species examined, ranged
   from 0.0306 to 0.1072. Type specimens are deposited in the Entomological
   Museum, Northwest A & F University, Yang ling, Shaanxi Province, China
   (NWAFU).

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF VITRONURA (COLLEMBOLA: NEANURIDAE) FROM SHANGHAI,
   EASTERN CHINA, WITH DNA BARCODES.
AU Gao, Yu
   Bu, Yun (ybu@sibs.ac.cn) 
   Palacios-Vargas, Jose G.
SO Florida Entomologist
VL 95
IS 4
PS 1142-1153
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Vitronura setaebarbulata sp. nov. and V quartadecima sp. nov. are
   described from Shanghai, China. V setaebarbulata sp. nov. is
   characterized by its heavy barbulate macrosetae, very granulated
   tubercles, dorsointemal tubercles on head coalescent and very close each
   other, mandible with three big teeth, apical one with denticules and
   maxilla with one of the 2 lamellae trifurcated. V quartadecima sp. nov.
   is characterized by having 14 tubercles on head, well isolated each
   other, smooth body setae and mandible with three big teeth, apical one
   with denticules. The COI barcode sequences were sequenced for four
   individuals of V setaebarbulata sp. nov. and twelve individuals of V
   quartadecima sp. nov. respectively. No genetic divergence between
   individuals of same species was found, and the divergence of nucleotides
   between the two new species is 18.54%. An updated key to world species
   of Vitronura is also provided.
C1 Bu, Yun; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Plant Physiol & Ecol, Shanghai, 200032,
   China, China.
EM ybu@sibs.ac.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0015-4040
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Vitronura quartadecima; Vitronura setaebarbulata [Shanghai /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Collembola

   subordinate taxa, P. 1150; Key to species, Updated key, p. 1152]. 
   Vitronura quartadecima (Collembola): [Sp nov, Shanghai, P. 1147].

AN ZOOR14909036582
DT Article
TI CONGRUENCE BETWEEN ACOUSTIC TRAITS AND GENEALOGICAL HISTORY REVEALS A
   NEW SPECIES OF DENDROPSOPHUS (ANURA: HYLIDAE) IN THE HIGH ANDES OF
   COLOMBIA.
AU Guarnizo, Carlos E. (cguarnizo@utexas.edu) 
   Escallon, Camilo
   Cannatella, David
   Amezquita, Adolfo
SO Herpetologica
VL 68
IS 4
PS 523-540
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 18
AB The High-Andean Frog (Dendropsophus labialis) is distributed along the
   Eastern Andes of Colombia between 1900 and 3600 in. We analyzed multiple
   traits to determine if acoustics and morphology covary with genealogical
   history or if they evolved following independent trajectories. We
   generated a phylogeny of D. labialis populations with the use of
   mitochondrial ribosomal gene (12S, val-RNA, 16S) and nuclear gene
   (proopiomelanocortin A (POMC)) sequences. Two well-supported clacks that
   correspond to geographic distribution were recovered. Acoustic variation
   diverges according to genealogical history, but external morphology does
   not follow this pattern. The strong and congruent divergence observed in
   acoustic and genetic characters indicates that these two chides
   correspond to morphologically cryptic, parapatric species. We describe
   the Northern Clack as a new species (Dendropsophus luddeckei; the
   Southern Clade retains the name D. labialis). The low level of molecular
   divergence between two outgroup species, Dendropsophus pelidna and
   Dendropsophus meridensis, suggests D. pelidna is a junior subjective
   synonym of D. meridensis.
C1 Guarnizo, Carlos E.; Univ Texas Austin, Sect Integrat Biol, 1 Univ
   Stn,CO930, Austin, TX, 78712, USA, USA.
EM cguarnizo@utexas.edu
RI Guarnizo, Carlos E/A-6383-2011
OI Guarnizo, Carlos E/0000-0001-7324-1241
SC Zoology
SN 0018-0831
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Dendropsophus luddeckei [Colombia /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Hylidae
OR Dendropsophus labialis - (Peters 1863) (Hylidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 529]. 
   Dendropsophus luddeckei (Hylidae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 535]. 
DI 10.1655/HERPETOLOGICA-D-10-00038
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14909036582
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14909036583
DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF NYCTIMYSTES (ANURA: HYLIDAE) FROM PAPUA NEW GUINEA.
AU Kraus, Fred (fkraus@hawaii.edu) 
SO Herpetologica
VL 68
IS 4
PS 541-550
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB I describe a new species of hylid frog of the genus Nyctimystes from
   Fergusson Island off the southeastern peninsula of New Guinea. The new
   species is distinctive in being of moderate size, lacking a tubercle or
   lappet on the heel, and in having a vocal sac and slits, palpebral
   venation of vertically oriented lines with few cross-connections, basal
   webbing between the fingers, orange-yellow flash markings in the groin
   and hidden surfaces of the thighs, and a venter heavily flecked with
   brown. The new species is currently known only from the type locality,
   but it may range inure widely across the D'Entrecasteaux Islands. It is
   morphologically most similar to N. persimilis from the mountains of the
   adjacent mainland of New Guinea.
C1 Kraus, Fred; Bishop Museum, 1525 Bernice St, Honolulu, HI, 96817, USA,
   USA.
EM fkraus@hawaii.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0018-0831
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia
DE Nyctimystes cryptochrysos [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Hylidae
OR Nyctimystes cryptochrysos (Hylidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 542].

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF XENOSAURUS FROM THE SIERRA MADRE ORIENTAL, MEXICO.
AU Woolrich-Pina, Guillermo A.
   Smith, Geoffrey R. (smithg@denison.edu) 
SO Herpetologica
VL 68
IS 4
PS 551-559
PD Dec 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB There are currently eight described species in the lizard genus
   Xenosaurus. However, given their restricted habitat use (primarily
   limited to crevices or holes in rocks) and the limited ability to
   disperse among isolated populations, it is likely that more species of
   Xenosaurus await discovery and description. Herein we describe a new
   species of Xenosaurus from the Sierra Madre Oriental in the State of
   Hidalgo, Mexico. This new species differs from previously described
   species in lacking a neck band and in having two pale lines that angle
   up from the jaws and extend parasagittally along the neck.
C1 Smith, Geoffrey R.; Denison Univ, Dept Biol, Granville, OH, 43023, USA,
   USA.
EM smithg@denison.edu
RI Woolrich-Pina, Guillermo GAWP/P-2837-2018; Woolrich-Pina, Guillermo
   Alfonso/AAM-8342-2020
OI Woolrich-Pina, Guillermo Alfonso/0000-0002-3421-7246
SC Zoology
SN 0018-0831
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America
DE Xenosaurus tzacualtipantecus [Mexico /  / New species].

AB Description of a new species of the genus Fessonia (Acari: Prostigmata:
   Smarididae) from Iran. - Fessonia torshizica Salarzehi & Hajiqanbar n.
   sp. is described from larvae collected in the soil of vineyards in
   northeastern Iran. This is the second species currently known from
   larvae in the genus Fessonia. Some morphological characters of the new
   species are compared with its only congener, E papillosa (Hermann 1804).

TI A new species of Ceratophysella from Peru (Collembola: Hypogastruridae).
AU Palacios-Vargas, Jose G. (troglolaphysa@hotmail.com) 
   Bocanegra, Thalia
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 119
IS 4
PS 417-423
PD Decembre 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Ceratophysella from Peru (Collembola: Hypogastruridae).
   - Ceratophysella tupamara sp. nov. from Iquitos, Peru is described and
   illustrated. It is easy to distinguish from Ceratophysella denticulata
   (Bagnall, 1941), the only species of the genus previously cited from
   Peru, by its trilobed apical bulb of antennal segment IV, the number of
   unguicular teeth and the body chaetotaxy.

AN ZOOR14909036831
DT Article
TI A new species of Neoechinorhynchus (Eoacanthocephala:
   Neoechinorhynchidae) from Pachyurus bonariensis (Perciformes:
   Sciaenidae) from the Parana River basin in Argentina, with comments on
   two other species of the genus.
AU Arredondo, Nathalia J. (arredondonj@bg.fcen.uba.ar) 
   Gil de Pertierra, Alicia A.
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 119
IS 4
PS 425-439
PD Decembre 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species of Neoechinorhynchus (Eoacanthocephala:
   Neoechinorhynchidae) from Pachyurus bonariensis (Perciformes:
   Sciaenidae) from the Parana River basin in Argentina, with comments on
   two other species of the genus. - Neoechinorhynchus (Hebesoma)
   colastinense sp. n. is described from the intestine of Pachyurus
   bonariensis a freshwater fish from Parana River basin. The new species
   is characterized by having a cylindrical trunk, elongated but swollen
   anteriorly; a spherical proboscis with a prominent apical organ; the
   anterior circle of hooks very large, alternating in 2 levels, separated
   from more posterior circles of hooks, but sometimes surpassing the hooks
   of the middle and posterior circles; a relatively long neck; the male
   reproductive system occupying 78-81% (79%) of the trunk length; the
   female reproductive system occupying 27-39% (32%) of the trunk length;
   and eggs elongated with polar prolongation of the fertilization
   membrane. Members of the species can be distinguished easily from the
   other species of South American Neoechinorhynchus Stiles & Hassall, 1905
   because they are the only ones with characteristics of the subgenus
   Hebesoma. Additionally, two other species are recorded for the first
   time in Argentina: Neoechinorhynchus (Neoechinorhynchus) macro nucleatus
   Machado Filho, 1954 from Lycengraulis grossidens and N. (N.) pimelodi
   Brasil-Sato & Pavanelli, 1998 from several species of Pimelodus. The
   presence of an apical organ at the proboscis tip is recorded in the new
   species and N. (N.) macronucleatus. Studies using scanning electron
   microscopy revealed the presence of non-rimmed pores in the tegument
   throughout the trunk, neck and proboscis of all three species. A key to
   the South American species of Neoechinorhynchus is provided.
C1 Arredondo, Nathalia J.; Univ Buenos Aires, Fac Ciencias Exactas & Nat,
   Ciudad Univ,Int Guiraldes 2160,Pabellon 11,40 Pis, Buenos Aires, DF,
   RA-1053, Argentina, Argentina.
EM arredondonj@bg.fcen.uba.ar

   Land zones; Neotropical region; South America

DT Article
TI Civizelotes new genus, and other new or little known Zelotinae (Araneae,
   Gnaphosidae).
AU Senglet, Antoine (a.senglet@bluewin.ch) 
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 119
IS 4
PS 501-528
PD Decembre 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Civizelotes new genus, and other new or little known Zelotinae (Araneae,
   Gnaphosidae). - Civizelotes, a new genus of gnaphosid spiders, is
   established and divided in four species groups. Notes are given on the
   mating mechanisms of C. medianus (Denis) in the C. civicus-group. First
   descriptions are given of the male of Z. argoliensis (C. L. Koch, 1839),
   of the female of Drassyllus villicoides (Giltay, 1932) comb. n., the
   female of Civizelotes dentatidens (Simon, 1914) comb. n., the female of
   C. medianus (Denis, 1935) comb. n. C. medianoides sp. n., C. ibericus
   sp. n., and Heser hispanus sp. n. Transferred to different genera are:
   C. civicus (Simon, 1878) comb. n., C. caucasius (L. Koch, 1866) comb.
   n., C. solstitialis (Levy, 1998) comb. n., Heser nilicola (O.
   P.-Cambridge, 1874) comb. n., H. schmitzi (Kulczynski, 1899) comb. n.,
   H. bernardi (Marinaro, 1967) comb. n., H. bonneti (Marinaro, 1967) comb.
   n., and H. incisupalpis (Levy, 1998) comb. n. Zelotes balcanicus
   Deltshev, 2006 is removed from the synonymy of Z. argoliensis.

DT Article
TI Leptopsalis foveolata sp n., a new species of Stylocellidae from
   Thailand that displays a novel morphological feature in the suborder
   Cyphophthalmi (Arachnida, Opiliones).
AU Clouse, Ronald M. (rclouse@amnh.org) 
   Schwendinger, Peter J.
SO Revue Suisse de Zoologie
VL 119
IS 4
PS 529-546
PD Decembre 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Leptopsalis foveolata sp. n., a new species of Stylocellidae from
   Thailand that displays a novel morphological feature in the suborder
   Cyphophthalmi (Arachnida, Opiliones). - Leptopsalis foveolata sp. n., a
   species of Southeast Asian mite harvestman with an exceptional
   morphology, is described. Males and females of this species bear rows of
   deep pits on the dorsal and ventral side of the posterior end of their
   body. These pits are strongly granular but do not bear obvious pores or
   especially dense concentrations of micropores. Also, many of the large
   granules on the body surface are flattened and digitated, and many
   around the pits are grooved. This is a new morphological feature in the
   suborder Cyphophthalmi, and its function is not clear. The species is
   only known from the type locality, Mt Sankalakheeree in Pattani
   Province, southern Thailand, formerly known as Bukit Besar.
C1 Clouse, Ronald M.; Amer Museum Nat Hist, Div Invertebrate Zool, Cent Pk
   W & 79th St, New York, NY, 10024, USA, USA.
EM rclouse@amnh.org
SC Zoology
SN 0035-418X

   Eurasia; Asia
